DIV1.P: 'Tis Well it's no Worse: A COMEDY.
As it is Performed at the THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE, BY HIS MAJESTY'S SERVANTS.

Q.L: Va, mon Enfant, prend ta Fortune.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for W. GRIFFIN, at Garrick's-Head, in Catharine-Street, in the Strand.

DIV1.HEAD: TO MRS. ABINGTON.
DIV1.P: THE great service you have done this comedy, by your admirable per∣formance in it, obliges the author to return you his publick thanks; he does so most sincerely; and, at the same time, begs leave to inscribe it to you, as you have certainly the best right to what you have made.

It is not the first time, indeed, that the writer of this piece has been in∣debted to the abilities of Mrs. Abing∣ton: those persons who remember her in the Hypocrite, (and such as have seen that play, I think, cannot have easily forgot her) must allow, that she made a no less striking figure in Charlotte, (the elegant, and sprightly Maria of the Nonjuror) than she now does, in the flaunting, flippant, noisy chambermaid.

But, while I am endeavouring to acknowledge my obligations to you, let not my complaisance for a lady, make me overlook a friend to whom I am equally bound; I mean Mr. King: who, by all accounts, has supported the character of Muskato in a manner even to force applause from enemies.

I wish I could devise a better me∣thod than I here take to express my gratitude to you both; my praises can add nothing to your reputation, nor to his: however, I shall have a less mean opinion of my writings, than I otherwise would, while they afford either of you an opportunity of inspir∣ing the public, with fresh admiration of your talents.

CLOSER.SALUTE: I am, Madam, Your most obliged, and most obedient Servant,

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P: WHEN this Comedy was put into Mr. Garrick's hands, it was delivered to him as a piece, the chief merit of which consisted in the Intrigue; and, as such, he agreed with the Author, that it was a very great curiosity. It must be owned, indeed, in justice to his discernment, that he thought the exhibition of it a hazardous attempt; however, he at the same time declared, that if the Play did not too far clash with the prejudices of re∣vailing taste, he thought it had an undoued right to success. On what ground the writer founded his hopes, that these prejudices would not be unreasonably urged against it; or, if they were, that his Comedy would in the end get the better of them; a short account of the piece from whence he took it, will pro∣bably be the best explanation.

THE original of the Play, now laid before the public, is called El Escondido y la Tapada, The Hidden Man and the Veil'd Woman; and is counted the master-piece of the most famous among the Spanish Dramatic Poets, Don Pedro Calderon de la Barca; who, through Moliere, Corneille, Le Sage, Boissy, &c. has provided Vanbrugh, Centlivre, Cibber, and Steel, with The Mistake, The False Friend, The Wonder, The Busy Body, The Kind Impostor, The Lady's Philosophy, and The Lying Lover, all English Comedies, which have been received upon the stage with the warmest marks of approbation.

HOWEVER, neither these former instances of Calderon's favourable reception among us, nor the forcible manner in which the writer was struck, when he first perused this parti∣cular Comedy of his, were the sole motives that induced him to adopt it. In a little French book, called Histoire des Fêtes Gallantes des Rois de France, he found it praised as a miracle of invention and dramatic situations; and that in the year 1668 it was one of the plays that had been performed during the famous feast at Versailles, given by Louis XIV. to his court, and a vast concourse of the first people in Europe. In another book, where it is mentioned, he found that in November 1716 it was again put into French, and acted under the title of L'Amant Cachè & la Dame Voilée, first at the castle of the celebrated
Mareschal Noailles, in honour of his daughter's marriage with Prince Charles; and afterwards by the comedians in Paris, (to whom the Mareschal made it a present) with the greatest success. Lastly, in the year 1769, it was once more translated into the French language, by Mons. Lanquit, a Counsellor of Parliament, and an excellent writer and critic; who, after much praise of the poet and the piece, (which he names La Cloison, The Pannel) speaking of Don Carlos and Muskato, being locked up in the unfurnished house, he says, “it is an incident the most theatrical that can be imagined, and nothing is so ineresting and so singular as the situations it produces.”

BUT I shall perhaps be told, that these tes∣timonies in favour of the Original may still leave the Copy without excuse; and as I be∣lieve they who dislike the Play will hardly take my word, when I tell them I have done it no harm, I must refer them to the Spanish original, or the French translation, (which is literal) to enable them to decide the point. I shall only add, in this place, that the critics have long agreed to make a distinction be∣tween Comedies of Character and Comedies of Intrigue; and notwithstanding these are undoubtedly the best, which are composed of a due portion of both, I never understood, from all I have read about the matter, that Comedy forfeited her name by attaching her∣self to either, particularly the latter; in which
the great difficulty of the dramatic art seems to lie. Nor can I find, tho' it has been of late years the fashion for Comedy to address herself rather to the Heart and Understanding This sort of Comedy, if pleasantry be not intirely excluded, is certainly the most commendable of all; and the Author begs leave to observe, that the Maid of the Mill, a piece written by himself, however trifling in other circumstances, was the first sentimental Drama that had appeared on the English stage for near forty years., than the Fancy, that she may not address her∣self to the Fancy solely, (as in this piece) without calling her title at all in question.

THESE propositions agreed to, I hope I shall be pardoned for thinking that a reader, or spectator, not violently exceptious, who will sit down with a hearty desire to be amused, may find great entertainment from Calderon's Play. Nay, even the professed critic will meet something not to be displeased with, particularly in the Plot; in which is preserved a perfect unity of action, at the same time that it is branched into a multitude of incidents. These incidents, again, are all naturally prepared; rising one from the other, without confusion, without obscurity; and with less to excuse, on the plea of necessity, (a plea which in some cases a judicious critic will always be ready to admit) than could be easily supposed, in such a tissue of events, drawn from a simple circumstance. Nor, let me say, will a candid judge, who knows how
to rate the merit of invention, be very apt to quarrel with such a Play, for a weak Scene, or unguarded Phrase; or for wanting, what in its nature it cannot have, laboured Dialogue, and high wrought Character.

To the performers in this Comedy, the English Author, or Translator, which ever he may be called, has great obligations; particularly to Mr. Reddish, who, in the character of Don Carlos, accepted of a part, purely to serve him, greatly below his merit; though his spirited action gives it consequence in the representation. To Mr. Parsons, Mr. Brereton, and Mr. Baddely, he is also very much obliged.

To Mr. Garrick he is indebted for—every thing; but, as they were given in a moment of necessity and disappointment, he must par∣ticularly thank him for his Prologue and Epilogue; the value of the gift being in no sort lessened to the receiver, by the short time taken to produce them.

LG.L: O Ho! there ye are!—Before one word I utter,
I must tell you, my dears—that I, Captain O Cutter,
With silent respect, will a thing or two say
About my relation who wrote this new play:
My cousin, poor soul's, in a damnable fright,
Becase why?—to amuse ye he takes great delight;
I said, fye, for shame!—what a man and be frightful?
A pale bashful Irishman's never delightful;
No conquests are gain'd, with such dread looks as those;
I told him, a man should not shrink at his foes;
That you were his friends, and would taste what he writ,
If he would not o'erload you with humour and wit;
He swore he would not be so wake and absurd;
And if I know my cousin, he'll not brake his word.
My cousin's no fool, at your reading and writing,
Tho' now for his play, he's as pale as a whiting.
I answer'd for you, which his heart has much eas'd,
That tho' you don't like it, I'm sure you'll be plas'd;
For they say that Old Nick, if he's plas'd, will be civil;
You'll like it, if not plas'd, to be unlike the Devil.
In short, my dear cousin has taken a prize;
I'm sure you'll applaud him, 'tis Spanish, my boys.
An old crazy vessel, ill built, rigg'd, and plann'd;
But now is ra-built, new rigg'd, and new mann'd,
And just ready to lance.—If, when it appears,
From this noble vessel, you'll give it three cheers,
'Twill lighten his heart, tho' it load not his purse,
And the rogue will cry out—'Tis well it's no worse.
From the head to the starn, thus let me address you,
To lend us your hands—for faith I'll not press you.
First Upper gallery.you in the top there, with bawling don't stun him;
As you'r stout, pray be marciful, don't fire upon him.
If First gallery.you on the quarter-deck will not befriend him,
Your swivels and small arms, faith, quickly will end him.
And if Pit.you between decks, my cousin don't favour,
But give him your broadsides, you sink him for ever.
And, O ye Boxes.sweet Craters, who sit in the cabin,
Whose privateer eyes are our hearts ever nabbing,
Do but awe with your cannon this critical The Pit.crew,
You'll charm Irish hearts, to your sex ever true,
That a son of St. Patrick's protected by you.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: WRITTEN BY The AUTHOR of the PROLOGUE.

LG.L: INSTEAD of an epilogue, round, smart, and terse,
Let poor simple me, and in more simple verse,
Just handle the text—It is well it's no worse.
The brat of this night, should you cherish and nurse,
And hush it, and rock it, tho' you fill not his purse,
The daddy will say, that—'Tis well it's no worse.
Or shou'd his strange fortune, turn out the reverse.
That his pockets you fill, tho' his play you shou'd curse,
Still our author will say—It is well it's no worse.
The town with each poet, will push, carte and tierce,
If the bard can so guard, that his buff you don't pierce,
Tho' you pink him a little—'Tis well it's no worse.
Should the play-house be full, tho' the criticks so fierce,
The managers, actors, and author asperse,
We shrug up our shoulders—'Tis well it's no worse.
But should you to damn, be resolv'd and perverse,
If quietly after, from hence you disperse,
We wish you good-night—and—It's well it's no worse.

DIV1.HEAD: 'Tis Well it's no Worse: A COMEDY.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A place supposed to be in the suburbs of Madrid: time, near the dusk of the evening. Don Carlos enters as from a journey, followed by Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: MUSKATO!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Signor Don Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What was it the clock struck as we passed by the convent?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Seven, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: 'Tis too light to venture into town yet; till it grows a little darker, let us stop here—have you tied the mules to the trees, as I ordered you?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I have tied the mules; but don't you think it would have been more in the natural order of things, if the riders had been tied first?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Neither more nor less, than that of the four, the beasts are the most reasonable creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: You think we are two madmen then.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Troth do I, Sir; with some little differ∣ence, however, between us.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: You would insinuate, I suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Oh nothing farther, Sir, than that you have the precedence in that, as you ought in all other things in which we are mutually concerned; you are mad, en maitre, as the French have it: I am mad, through complaisance, as it were; or interest; or to adapt myself to the company of my betters.

SP.SPEAKER: D Car.
SP.P: And how do you prove this, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk
SP.P: How do I prove it?—Thus—It is scarcely three months since we were obliged to make our escape from this good town of Madrid, after having killed a gentleman, brother to a certain lady, to whom, for some months before, you had been paying your addresses: and what is not a little ex∣traordinary, you were not only the professed ad∣mirer of his sister, but his rival at the same time with another lady, about whom you wisely took it into your heads to quarrel Well, after having fought ourselves out of Spain, we arrived safely and happily in Portugal; when, I know not upon what crotchet—for you never told me a word of your intention, till the moment you put it in practice—coming one evening suddenly into your lodgings—Maskato, says you—Here, your honour, says I—Get our boots, says you, and saddle the mules di∣rectly—I thought we were going to take the air in some of te pretty outlets about town—but the devil a bit—No sooner had we set foot on the road to Spain, than clapping your heels smartly to the sides of your beast, off you went in a hand gallop, and I followed—crick, crack—whip and spur, through tick and thin—till here we are at the gates of Madrid again.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: This is all very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: And yet you are surprized that I should think you a madman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P:
You are not unacquainted, Muskato, with the vioence of my passion for Marcella, the daughter of Don Guman de Ribbera—I loved her
from the first moment I saw her; but finding her prepossession in favour of a relation of her own, an unsurmountable bar to my wishes, I at length de∣termined to get the better of an inclination so un∣happily placed, and to that end cast my eyes upon another very beautiful woman, whom you are also acquainted with—Aurora, the sister of Don Pedro Paccheco.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Well, Sir, and being so mighty well ac∣quainted with all these things—as, to my sorrow, I most certainly am—but what signifies your going about to tell me this rigmiroll story now?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: There is a melancholy indulgence in discoursing upon the subjects of our uneasiness—I say then, my friend, I used every means possible to make myself really fall in love with Aurora; but my heart refused to be an accomplice in the inconstancy to which my reason advised me—for my misfortune, Don Alonzo, the brother of the beauty from whose power I endeavoured to free myself, was the pro∣fessed admirer of her whom I affected to serve—I one day saw them walking together on the Prado; I was willing to interrupt the tête à tête, and im∣mediately joined them—Aurora appeared pleased with my company; and after I came up, paid little attention to Don Alonzo—this piqued his pride—he took occasion to insult me—we drew our swords—I had the advantage—and, at the second pass, my antagonist lay dead at my feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: At mine, upon my honour, Sir, for there he fell—and a well timber'd fellow he was—I think I never saw a finer corps since I came into the world.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: This unlucky affair forced me to fly—and when I had been about two months in Por∣tugal, I received this letter from Aurora—(taking a letter from his pocket)—you may read it.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P:
You know I can't, and that's the reason you are so willing to let me—however, read it for
me; I have done more than that for you before now.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Listen then—After some general ex∣planations of complement and regard, are these words, “You know my brother is absent, and you cannot have a surer retreat than in my house, where the family will never think of searching for you: accept it I beseech you: you will be on the spot to manage your affairs; and I am persuaded nothing prevents your pardon, but your not being here to excite your friends to a proper zeal.”

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: And so, Sir, to convince Donna Aurora that you were not insensible of her obliging offer, you quitted Lisbon, where you were in peace and safety—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: In effect, Muskato, friends are seldom so sollicitous for us in our absence—I have therefore come to Madrid upon this invitation. In the day∣time I can conceal myself in Aurora's house; and at night, go out among some I dare trust, whose in∣terest, if warmly exerted, may be of the utmost service to me. And shall I confess, that I am not a little flattered with the thought, now I am here, of sometimes accidentally seeing the charming Marcella; and now and then, in an evening paying my homage under her window?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Why to be sure, Sir, that must be a comfort to a gentleman of your amorous disposition; and to speak the truth, I promise myself some little grati∣fication, in enjoyments of the same kind; for what between Beatrice, chamber-maid to Donna Mar∣cella, and Leonarda, the governante of Donna Aurora.—But I am sadly afraid we shall be executed before we have time to put any of those pretty fancies into practice.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Carlos, Muskato: Marcella, Beatrice, Coach∣man, and Servants behind the scenes. A sudden crash is heard, with screams and cracking of whips.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh heav'ns and earth!

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Kniac, kniac, kniac!

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Hey dey! what's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pedro, Lopez!

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Ge up! ge up I say.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Footm.
SP.P: Why, Diego, you have got into a ditch here.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Footm.
SP.P: Take the horses by the head, while I clap my shoulder to the wheel.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Come then loves, come—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Help, murder, help!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: A carriage is overturned with women in it; I must assist them let what will be the conse∣quence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Why Sir, are you—He's gone—

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Footm.
SP.P: (running across) Stay a little comrade, stay a little—I'll run to the house and inform my master of what has happen'd, and get somebody to our assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Hah, sure I shou'd know that livery! If ever I saw it in my life, 'tis Don Guzman de Rib∣bera's: his house is hard by, and I'll be hang'd if this is not his coach that's overturn'd—Who have we here?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Beatrice, with the coachman drunk; and a footman carrying a flambeaux.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh! you villain, you villain, see what you've done.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Why what have I done, Mrs. Beatrice? I hope I have done no harm to you, nor nobody else: Heav'n forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
Do you call it no harm to overturn us? My ruffles are torn off my arms; and see here what a condition my veil's in—It's not the first time
you've been like to serve us this way before: but my master deserves it, for keeping so long in his family, such a drunken sot as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Drunken! upon my honour, and as I am a christian, I have not tasted any thing wet this blessed day, except just now, against my will, a little ditch water.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Go, you are a nasty wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: But I knew well enough you would say I was drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Sancho, where's my lady?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Foot.
SP.P: A cavalier came to her assistance, and is leading her along.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And why did you not stay to attend her with the light? (The servant goes out.) My poor things will never be worth a farthing again, as long as the world stands.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: I knew as well as could be, they would say I was drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (coming forward.) Signora Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (starti.) Ah, who's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Don't you know your old friend and admirer?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Muskato!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Mercy on us, man, what brings you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Love, and my other misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Is your master with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: We never travel asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And are you ignorant of the consequence, should it be known that you are in Madrid? If either of you are catched, you'll certainly be hanged.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: But I hope we shan't be catched, if you are not so cruel as to betray us.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I shan't betray you, but I can tell you my old master has not forgot the death of his son; he is as implacable as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: And yet the death of his son was not our fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No matter for that; there is scarcely an alguazil in Spain, but has a warrant against you; so have a care of yourselves.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Carlos, leading Marcella; preceded by a servant with a stambeau.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Go before, and keep your light at a greater distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Dear Madam, how do you find yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh, pretty well, thanks to the civility of this cavalier. I only wish to know him, that I may acknowedge the favour as I ought.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (quitting her hand.) She will never be able to bear the sight of me, after killing her brother; I had better not discover myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: Oblige me, Sir, by making me acquainted with the gentleman to whom I am so much indebted.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (turning from her.) You confess I have been serviceable to you, Madam; that is happiness enough for me; wish not to know your benefactor, lest it should make you hate the benefit.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: What do you mean, Sir? I owe my life to you; if you will not accept of my acknowledge∣ments, give my friends, my father, leave—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (still turning from her.) You owe me no∣thing, Madam; I desire no acknowledgments; I dread them more than you did your danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: Sure there is something in that voice that I have heard before.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It is Don Carlos!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk
SP.P: My poor unfortunate master. Turn to her, Sir, turn to her, o'God's name, and don't be afraid; Donna Marcella is too generous to injure a miserable gentleman that loves her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (falling on his knees, and catching Marcella by the hand.) Beautiful Marcella! behold at your feet, the most unfortunate of men.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: Signor Don Carlos, pray Sir, pray, what brings you here? Let go my hand; you can't imagine the terror you have thrown me into.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: You know I adore you. Hear me ex∣culpate myself from the fatal offence which drove me for ever from your presence: by heav'ns, when your brother fell, through his own ungoverned passion—

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: Wound not my ears with the shocking recital, and leave me directly; you may do so in full security: the favour I have just received from you, warrants my letting you go unmolested.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Sir, here are people coming with more lights; we shall be seized before we can look about us.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: My honour is pledged for your safety, Don Carlos, if you depart immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Be it so, Madam; I'll trouble you no farther; but remember my life is in your hands more ways than one.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice, Don Guzman, Don Ferdinand, with servants, and lights.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why, what is all this? what is it all? The coach overturned, and my daughter and her maid in the mire! I never heard such a silly, strange, unaccountable, devilish thing since I was born. Oh, here are our young women. How did this accident happen to you, child? You are not hurt I hope; all your limbs are safe, no bones broke?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, there are no bones broke; but look what a condition I'm in; I shall never be able to wear a stitch of these cloaths again.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Who the devil cares whether you are or not; what do you trouble me about your rags for, you paltry hussy, when I am enquiring after your mistress's safety? I say, my dear, you are not hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, Sir, no; not much hurt, but exceed∣ingly terrified.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, but stretch out your arms, and walk about, that I may be satisfied there are no fractures, or dislocations.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: There are none, Sir; pray let us go home as fast as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ferdinand, take care of your cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Lean upon my arm, my dear, and fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: To talk to me about your dirty rags! (crossing Beatrice.) Diego, sirrah, how have you overturned the coach, you rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Sir, if you'll have patience, I'll tell you the whole affair, from first to last; and if your honour finds me blameable in any manner of way—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: He'll tell you he's drunk, Sir; but that he need not tell you, for it's easy enough to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Don't you be in a passion, Mrs. Beatrice. I say, Sir, the fault of this here affair lay all entirely in the horses; somebody gave the beasts something while I step'd into the public house, I believe; for as soon as I got on the box again, I found I should not be able to manage them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Dog, I tell you but this—

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P: Well, but hear me out, your honour; and if I don't make it as plain—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ferd.
SP.P: Come, Sir, come; you see it's in vain to talk to him now, and my cousin wants to get out of the air. Advance, there, with a flambeau?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, I'll talk to him tomorrow to some purpose, and strip his livery over his ears, I can tell him that; a careless, drunken, scoundrell. Go, somebody, and look after the horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachm.
SP.P:
Hold, hold; I'll go and look after them. Ge up, there.—This it is, to live under an arbi∣trary government; a man must not speak in his own defence: I wish I had been born in England; a good servant there can bid his master drive his coach himself, if he does not like how he's driven.
(hiccups, and staggers.) Its no comfort to get drunk in this slavish country.

DIV2.STAGE: Scene changes to a room, in Aurora's house. Aurora enters followed by Leonarda.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Undone! ruined! and undone past re∣demption.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I wish I could say any thing to comfort you, Ma'am: but, Heaven help me, I can't: how∣ever, I think it would have been better, some how, if you had not writ that letter to Don Carlos, to desire him to come back to Madrid; and since you did write it, it would have been better if he had not received it; and since he did receive it, it would have been better if he had not accepted the invitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: What a marvellous discoverer you are; no doubt any of these things would have been better, as matters now stand; but who could divine that my brother would return from Naples without giving me any notice of his intention; and that he should come at so critical a juncture?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Well, Ma'am, I can't help applauding my own surgacity, for I always thought your writing to Don Carlos would come to no good.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: And why did you not say so pray? I'm sure it was chiefly by your advice I did it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why yes, Ma'am, because I saw you pining and languishing; and to be sartin, I thought it a very genteel thing in Don Carlos to kill a gentle∣man for you, as no doubt it was; and I said it would be very hard, if he should suffer the law, which he must do, or live in banishment all his life, unless he could get his pardon; and how could he get his pardon so well, as by coming among his friends to partition for him; seeing the revengeful disposition of Don Guzman and his family.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well, let me hear no more of your prate, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Do you think, Ma'am, Don Carlos will be here to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I expected him last night, you know, and shall expect every moment 'till I hear farther from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: And bless us all, what do you intend to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Ask me no questions, I know not what to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Lord, Ma'am, there's no saying a word to you, you are so ill natur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: You have been able to pick nothing out of my brother's servant, you say, with regard to the business that has brought his master hither; there is certainly some mystery in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: That there is, Ma'am, as sure as can be; you may see it by the manner he carries himself. And it's my opinion the servant, tho' he's so close; knows more of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Softly, here is my brother.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Pedro, and a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Give me a chair, and have my gown and slippers ready, I shall undress presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (In Aurora's ear.) Mercy on us, how cross he looks.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Good evening to you, Sir; you have been out a great deal to day, and I am afraid have fatigued yourself: why don't you reach my brother a chair?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Time enough, time enough. (Throws himself into an arm chair) Go you, Sir, and get me a glass of water: or stay, let it alone; I wont have any. (clapping his hand on his forehead.) Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: You seem uneasy, Sir; has any thing hap∣pened to vex you while you were abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Do you know of nothing that has hap∣pened which ought to vex me?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P:
How can I possibly be acquainted with your concerns? Yet, to be plain with you, Sir, since you have started the subject, your unexpected coming
to Madrid, and your behaviour ever since yesterday that you arrived here, has raised some doubts in my mind; and inclined me to suspect, that somewhat more than ordinary has been the matter with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: And you really can form no idea of what that something more than ordinary should be?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: No, really.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: You would be glad to know it, I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Most certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Leonarda, and Lopez, leave the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (Aside.) With all my heart; I am very glad to be out of the way. [Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Pedro, Aurora.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: (Rising.) You know, sister, when our father died, a very considerable succession devolved to me: however, being then with my regiment at Naples, I did not come to take possession, but left every thing to your care and management.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you have had no reason to repent—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Pray hear me out. This confidence in your discretion naturally led me to expect that you would keep a more than ordinary guard upon all your actions; on the contrary, however, I had re∣peated advice from hence, that the honour of our family was in imminent danger from your want of prudence; a friend in particular, writ me word, that, in the month of April last, you left your lodg∣ings, with Don Alonzo de Ribbera; and that while you were walking together on the Prado, another cavalier came up, charged him sword in hand, and killed him on the spot. In a word, it is this intel∣ligence that has brought me here to Madrid. It is a duty I owe both to you, and myself, to find out the truth of these reports; and, if they prove au∣thentic, it will be my duty, to take such measures, as may prevent your running into the like disorders for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: It seems then, you give credit to the scan∣dalous fable, upon the scent of which you have run so far.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I shall deal plainly with you. I have been this day, in every place, where I thought it possible to have my doubts satisfied by enquiry; particularly at Don Guzman's, whose unfortunate son perished in the rencounter with Don Carlos de Pimentel. But, upon the whole, I know not whether absolutely to believe, or totally to discredit it. I find, both the young men, were known for your admirers; and the report certainly ran, that you were the lady present at their fatal dispute; how∣ever, being veiled, in the confusion that ensued upon Don Alonzo's falling, the woman, whoever she was, escaped without being positively known.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well then, Sir, I give you my word, and I expect you will rely upon it, that, whatever wicked, and idle stories might be propagated, I was not the lady present, when the two cavaliers you mention fought. What! can you suppose that I would go to walk on the Prado without an attendant; that I would suffer gentlemen to follow me there; and, above all, that I would be the occasion of a duel? Whoever wrote you such an account of me, ought to be punished for an impostor.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Leonarda.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Don Ferdinard, Sir, the nephew of Don Guzman de Ribbera, is below; and desires to be admitted to you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Don Ferdinand! shew him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (calling at the door.) Shew the gentleman up, Lopez.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Sister, retire into the next room for a few minutes; and I desire that what has just now passed between us, may go no farther to any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (Softly, as they go out.) Well, Ma'am, what was it he had to tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Oh, Leonarda, he knows all.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: What, Ma'am, does he know the history of the wainscot?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Hush! not that, thank Heaven; but every thing else.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Pedro, Don Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Don Pedro, I rejoice to find you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Your air speaks a mind in agitation; what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: You came to-day to my uncle's, to ask about the melancholy affair, in which my cousin, Don Alonzo, was killed by Don Carlos de Pimentel; I then told you all I knew of the matter, and that the assassin had escaped to Portugal.

SP.SPEAKER: D Ped.
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, I was mistaken; Don Carlos is at this moment in this very town of Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: How do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: About an hour ago, my cousin Marcella and her maid, were overturned in a coach, just by my uncle's house; going out to their assistance, we met two men, who endeavoured to shun us; coming back, we crossed them again; and, by the light of the flambeaux, which fell directly on their faces, I saw and knew one of them to be Don Carlos. I immediately gave a servant the word, and he has dogged him, and his man, to a little inn, where they put up two mules, they had with them; and on which, they appeared to be just come off a journey.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: You are positive you saw Don Carlos?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P:
I am as positive it was he, as that I this moment see you.—Now, as I am shortly to be married to my cousin, it is highly incumbent upon me to render myself acceptable to my uncle; and, I am certain, I can do nothing more likely to please him, than taking vengeance on the man who kill'd his son. I therefore expect that you will lend me
your assistance upon so interesting an occasion, and accompany me to the place where the servant is ready to lead us: either to see that I have no foul play done me in an assault; or to help me to seize the delinquent, and give him over to the officers of justice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I will most willingly do what you desire; and am particularly glad of an opportunity to be your second, in an affair in which I consider myself already as a party concerned—Lopez, my sword—Is your man now below?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: He waits at the door to conduct us.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Tell my sister, I shall be in again pre∣sently.

DIV2.STAGE: Leonarda, a footman, Aurora indisposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (running in.) Help, help; oh, my lady! my lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Donna Aurora is taken ill—Come, Lopez, come and assist me to recover her—Oh, here she is—Smell to this bottle, Ma'am—(giving her a little phial)—Bless my heart, such a sudden thing; if it has not given me a pain all down my back!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Some harsh words my brother said to me just now, had such an effect upon my weak spirits: but I'm a great deal better—You may leave us, Lopez—(sits down.)—shut the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Dear Ma'am, try to compose yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: What have we heard, Leonarda, what have we heard!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Very terrible things, to be sure, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don Carlos is arrived at Madrid, and my brother is gone to kill, or deliver him up to justice. I should have called them back—fallen at their feet—Oh, cruel, cruel stroke, of his and my ad∣verse fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P:
Well but, Ma'am, there may be some
mistake; and, after all, I think, if Don Carlos was actually come to Madrid, he would have been here before now; for consider the danger of his being seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Did you hear them say he was just arriv'd—Oh, too sure, too sure he is come; and they are gone to destroy him!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (A bell rings faintly.) Hist, Ma'am, hist!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: What ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Hark!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: How now!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (Bell rings again.) As I hope to be sav'd, I heard the little bell ring below; he's come here, and is now at the garden-door. [runs out.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Fly quick, good Leonarda, fly—If this be so, I am yet happy; and may still preserve him from the malice of his enemies. [follows Leonarda.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Aurora, Leonarda, Don Carlos, and Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Beautiful Aurora, let me kiss your hand; I find myself alive, but in the pleasure of seeing you once again.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: I salute you too, sweet Signora Leonarda—but your lips, if you please; for I am not so easily satisfied as my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: You cannot think how rejoiced I am to see you, at this moment: yet, I fear, the asylum I have to offer you, will not prove so much to our wishes, as my letters to Portugal made you hope; for my brother arrived here, from Italy, yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Your brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I had no notice of his coming; otherwise, you may be sure, I should have apprized you, that you might have deferred your journey; at least, for some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: I thought Don Pedro had been with the Spanish regiments at Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P:
He was; but, wou'd you believe it, some
devil wrote him word of your master's duel with Don Alonzo; and that they quarrell'd about my lady: and he's come here for no versal purpose, but to find out the truth of it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: It will be impossible for me to stay in your house then.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Why so?—The accident of my brother's coming, may, for some time, put you in a disagree∣able situation, but not in a desperate one; I have prepared a retreat for you, where his utmost cunning will never be able to find you.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Ay, Ma'am, but the constables—

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Nor they, neither—hear my lady out.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: This house consists, like many others in Madrid, but of two stories: the upper, I occupy myself; the lower, which, on my father's death, I found I had no occasion for, I let to one Octavio, a wine-merchant: on this division of the building, a back stair-case, which made the communication between the two stories, with a small closet adjoin∣ing, became useless; and, by mutual consent, was stopped up, by a partition on the side of the apart∣ment below, as well as on this. When I had thoughts of bringing you back to Madrid, it occurred to me, that the partition on my side might again be secretly opened, and prepared in such a manner, as would effectually screen you from any search, should it ever be suspected that you were in the house: ac∣cordingly, the thing is done, (going to the back scene, she lifts up a pannel, which discovers the head of a stair-case) and this moveable pannel, will, when you please, admit you into a place of security; and, when fastened on the inside—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Excuse me, Ma'am, I have too grateful a sense of your kindness, to avail myself of a retreat, which must expose you. In this emergency, the most simple way is to return to the place from whence I came.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P:
That's my advice, Sir; let us go to the
inn directly, take our mules, o'God's name, and set off.—Ladies, my master, and I, have the honour of wishing you all health and happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Oh, hold! Don Carlos, you must not go to the inn, unless you have a mind to run into the jaws of inevitable destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: You have, by some accident or other, been seen, since you came to Madrid, by young Fer∣dinand, the nephew of Don Guzman de Ribbera. His servant dogg'd you to your inn; and he, and my brother, are just gone in search of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: This comes of your not putting on the mask you bought at Salamanca, as I advis'd you. Why, Sir, will you be so obstinate?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (a knocking at the door.) Oh, Heavens, Ma'am, your brother knocks.

SP.SPEAKER: D Car.
SP.P: Don't be alarmed; we have arms to de∣fend ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (getting behind his master.) No, no, ladies, don't be alarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Talk not of defence, I beseech you; but in pity to me, and out of regard to yourself, go into the place I have shewn you for this night: my bro∣ther will certainly go out early in the morning; and we will then consult together for your better and safer accommodation.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: What the lady says, Sir, is just and reason∣able—I have considered the matter; and, if you don't do it, I'll give myself up to justice imme∣diately, and try to be admitted king's evidence.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I'll do any thing for your safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: For my safety be it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Here, here, get you in. The closet's on the left hand, where you'll find a bed and a pallet: we'll be sure to come to you early in the morning; and, in the mean time, for your lives, don't come out upon any account whatsoever.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: No, upon no account.—Come, let us go into the next room.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (lifting up the pannel.) Hip, Signora Leo∣narda, won't you leave us a bottle, and a crust?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Feel in the closet.

DIV2.STAGE: Scene changes to an anti-chamber in the same house.
Don Pedro enters, sheathing his sword, followed by Don Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: So, at length we are got into, at least, a temporary shelter. Did you take notice whether any one pursued us?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I know not that; but I heard your name mentioned, more than once, by the crowd that ga∣thered about us.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: What do you here? Why don't you get to your own house?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: You cannot think me capable of such baseness: I have been the innocent means of draw∣ing you into this misfortune; you were known, though I was not; and I will either see you out of danger, or partake it with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Who is the person we have wounded?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I think some one said, the secretary of the Duke of Medina Sidonia.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, Signor Octavio, the wine-merchant below, desires to speak to you.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Octavio.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I understand, Don Pedro, you have had a scuffle in the street; you are known; and the person you have wounded, is the Duke of Medina Sidonia himself; who was going, incog. to the lodgings of a courtezan, in the quarter where you assaulted him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Fatal accident!—the Duke himself!

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: As a neighbour, and friend to your family, I am come to advise you to abscond without delay. The Duke's relations are proud and vindictive; and should he die, the worst consequences are to be ap∣prehended. In my opinion, indeed, you ought to take every thing belonging to you out of these apartments directly; for, depend upon it, as soon as an order can be procured from court, the officers of the police will be here; and, find who or what they will, they'll seize all without mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Why do you stand like one confounded? Do you not hear what Signor Octavio says? You and your family must be gone from hence; I will stay behind, and see your goods removed with all possible diligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: What is most valuable, may be put into my warehouse, in half an hour: and if Don Pedro will commit the key of his apartments to my charge, I will do my utmost to quash whatever enquiries may be made after him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Get a coach to the door, and call hither my sister and her maid; I must dispose of them in safety, the first thing I do.—My dear friend, had not you cried out, "That is the man," when you saw the person musfled coming towards us, I should not have drawn my sword upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: The fault was entirely the Duke's: had he discovered, instead of preparing to defend, him∣self, when he was called on to surrender, we should have acknowledged our error, and desired his pardon.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Aurora and Leonarda; Octavio, at the same time, going out, and afterwards returning with ser∣vants, to whom he appears to give directions about unfurnishing the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: What are your commands, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P:
To tell you, wretched creature, that you were born for my destruction, as well as my disho∣nour:
had not your misconduct brought me to Madrid, I might have escaped what has this night happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Why, what has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Don Ferdinand came hither just now; to desire I would accompany him on an affair of ho∣nour, but we have missed the person we went in search of, and by mistake assaulted another, who proves to be the duke of Medina Sidonia.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well, Sir, and what—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I must withdraw immediately to a place of safety; think not however, I will leave you any more at your own disposal, to add infamy to my misfortunes; a coach is already sent for, and late as it is, before we part, I will see you and your maid safely lodged with our cousin Matilda, abbess of the Ursuline nunnery.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I do not want to argue the matter with you: I have told you that my safety requires I should absent myself; and I will not leave you be∣hind.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I'm sure I'll not go into a nunnery.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Then I'm sure you shall go into the street.

DIV2.STAGE: [A knocking is heard, and a man comes with a step-ladder, which he sets against the back∣scene, to take down a picture.]

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Heav'n's and earth! what are these people doing?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Ask no questions; whatever is done is necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well but, Sir, I can't stir any where to∣night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: By Heav'ns, you must, and shall! The coach now stops at the door; and no where will I suffer you to go out of this place, but into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Oh, Lord, Ma'am, what will become of Don Carlos!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: (Partly overhearing.) Eh! how! what will become of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Nothing, Sir, nobody, I am only going for my lady's veil.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: The night's dark enough to hide her face without it. Come back here, Mistress: open the door there: come, give me both your hands (seezing them both, one in each hand:) nay, no struggling.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well but, Sir, brother, let me speak to you. Was ever so unfortunate a creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon
SP.P: Don't pull me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Follow me quietly then. Signor Oc∣tavio, I leave every thing to your prudent ma∣nagement: You, Don Ferdinand, shall hear from me. Why, sister, will you expose yourself, by this extravagant behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Kill me, rather than—

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Ah! (he forces them out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: (to the servant) Make what haste you can to get out the furniture, and let us lock up the doors immediately.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: The room in Aurora's apartments, in which is the moveable partition. The room appears unfurnished; Don Carlos lits up the pannel, and afterwards comes out, followed by Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: IT must certainly be day-light.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P:
Day-light! Zounds, Sir, what do you talk of? Its nearer noon than sun-rise: here's a clock that never fails me (striking his belly;) and,
if we have not been in this rat-hole thirteen hours, by any measurer of time in Castile, I'll be content to be carried from hence to Mexico, stowed in a beer barrel.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Surely, Aurora has forgot us; and yet that's impossible too: let us advance a little; gently, every thing's very quiet, Muskato; they are cer∣tainly asleep still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: May be so, Sir; I can only say they are slugabeds then; and that they lie longer in a morn∣ing, than people who regard their health ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Did not you hear somebody's voice?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, a man in the street, crying birch-brooms.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: But, sure, Muskato, either my eyes de∣ceive me, or this is not the room we were in last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: The room! Stay, why no; where the de∣vil's all the furniture? I think there were pictures, and chairs, and glasses—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: There were, no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: And, if I remember right, these walls were hung with tapestry.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Go to the door, and call softly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (on tipoe) Hist, hist, Leonarda!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Have a care, Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (louder) Leonarda! (louder still) Leona—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Is the fellow bewitch'd? You'll raise the house upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Not I, indeed, Sir; for, in my opinion, thete's nobody in the house to be raised: I fancy they have left us tenants at large: let's see a little farther (putting in his head at a door.) Hey dey! I believe we have had an auction here last night; if so, the bidders were obliged to take the goods off the premises as soon as purchas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What extravagancies are you uttering?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P:
Or, perhaps, a gang of house-breakers
broke in: they understood their business to a nicety, upon my word; for they seem not to have left so much as a joint-stool behind them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Come from thence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, do you rather come here, and judge for yourself. If ever I saw a room cleaner picked to the walls, I wish I may be shot. From the silence too, one should imagine the family lie murder'd in their beds; in which case we have had a lucky escape.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: There was a remarkable disturbance in the house, soon after we were shut up, that we both took notice of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Knocking and hammering, I remember it, Sir; and it was then, I suppose, that they were making conveyance of the goods and chattles.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Aurora and her maid charged us not to stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I wanted to get up for all that, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: This is the most extraordinary thing I ever met with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Hold, Sir, I find a certain boldness, or cou∣rage, come upon me; it may be owing to hunger; but no matter: I will venture forth to explore the contiguous apartments, and make you acquainted with my discoveries. I hope, at least, they have left us a little bread and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Carlos
SP.P: I feel a sudden alarm and terror, which I am un∣able to account for. This room has certainly been unfurnish'd during the night; and for what purpose? Something more than ordinary it must be owing to; and, perhaps, the design may be treason against me; yet, how against me? How is it possible? But there's no time for reflection; at any rate it will be impolitic in me to remain in a place, under such suspicious circumstances. Muskato! Muskato! (calling) I'll draw my sword; and, if any one at∣tempts to oppose our passage—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: What's the matter with you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Let us go from hence directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: How, through the key-holes? The doors are all double locked.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: By the windows then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: They have bars, on the outside, as thick as mill-posts.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Is there nobody in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Not a creature, except ourselves; nor a cranny left for a fly to get out at. I have been all through the rooms; and every thing's gone that they could conveniently carry off: in the kitchen, however; I found a few dry crusts; here they are; 'tis true I might conceal them for my own eating; but, friends in affliction should be generous to one another.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I am in amaze!

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Will you have a bit, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Certainly, was a man to rack his ima∣gination, in order to conceive a more singular ad∣venture, it would be hardly possible to do it. Au∣rora invites me hither, secure in the absence of her brother; he unexpectedly arrives a day before me; she shuts me up in a closet, against my will, to hide me from him; and, in a few hours that I am in the house, it is totally turned upside down; and I am left alone in it, without so much as a passage by which I can make my escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: "Well, be sure to come to you early in in the morning; and, in the mean time, for your lives don't come out upon any account whatever." (dashing his hat upon the ground) Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What fury possesses you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P:
These, Sir, as I take it, you may remem∣ber to have been the words that issued, last night, from the sweet lips of our good natured friends,
and benefactresses, when they were shoving us into the hole there.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Well what would you infer from thence? You don't suspect Aurora of perfidy; consider what joy she testify'd upon seeing us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: To be sure, Sir, her snare was not laid for nothing; and she was glad to have us fall into it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Then, was ever consternation more strongly painted than hers, when she thought. I should meet her brother, who was gone out in pur∣suit of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: All a lye; she saw we were likely to escape, and trumpt up that story to make sure of us; but pray, Sir, look round, and give me leave to ask you one simple question; for what reason do you think Don Pedro, or smebody else, has unfurnished this house so suddenly?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I can't imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Now, to me, it is as clear as the sun at noon-day: having you in their power, and being determined to sacrifice you, they mov'd off the goods beforehand, that they might not be exposed to confiscation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I ad formerly a master-key to this house; but, when I was going to Portugal, I gave it back to Aurora: little did I think I should ever come to stand in such need of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Well but, Sir, a truce with complaining, and let us consider what's to be done; for, as I take it, active measures will be necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I see but one means for our delivery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Give me a glympse of it, for I am so thick sighted of myself that I can discover never a one.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: The apartment below is occupied by a merchant; I will discover myself to him: it is better to run the risk of that confidence than to stay here to be assassinated.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: And how shall we contrive to make this merchant acquainted with our distress?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: By knocking at the partition at the foot of the stair-case.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Well but, stay, Sir, don't go about things hand over head; what if, at the first stroke, this merchant, and his people, should take us for thieves, break in upon us at once, and knock us on the head? Or, take it another way, suppose they should call the constables, before we have an opportunity to explain ourselves? In our present situation, I ap∣prehend we should not be better off.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (advancing, and stopping short) Hold, Muskato! did not you hear a noise?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, a damnable one (a noise without.) I'm afraid its all over with us.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: The noise comes from the great door below; it is in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I'll go then—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Stop, blockhead—

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: And tell them we have not the key.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Stay were you are (noise again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: If I mistake not egregiously, they are striv∣ing to break in (the noise increases;) let me just go to the door, and peep through the key-hole.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Do so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (returning) Oh, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: How now!

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: We are undone!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What do you fall upon your knees for? Is the fellow mad? Stand up, and tell me what you have seen: who's at the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Fifty!

SP.SPEAKER: D Car.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Serjeants of mace, and catchpoles, armed with bludgeons, and muskets (noise again) don't you hear them breaking open the door?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Once, again, I desire you to stand up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, yes, we're done for (noise again.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: They are breaking open the door, sure enough, whoever they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus
SP.P: They are what I tell you; I saw them with my eyes; and they are sent by that villain, Don Pedro, to take us alive. You will probably be put to the torture: take my advice; here's one of my garters; you'll find a hook behind the wain∣scot—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Good Heavens! Can I suspect a gentle∣man, like Don Pedro, of a proceeding so base as this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus
SP.P: A lady and a gentleman too, Sir; Don Pedro and Donna Aurora; the devil a barrel the better herring; and the waiting-woman too: they are all in the plot.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: The door opens; what shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I'll go up the kitchen chimney.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: No, let us rather retire to our hiding place, and barricade ourselves as well as we can. I will sell my life as dear as possible.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Octavio, and several officers; some of whom dis∣perse themselves about the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Come in, gentlemen, come in, and wel∣come; but why force the door? I had the key in my possession, and would have willingly opened it for you.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off
SP.P: I act in the king's name, and give no ac∣count

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: You'll tell me what you want, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Off.
SP.P: I am not obliged to do that either, unless I like it: however, since you are curious about the mat er, I want a gentleman, called Don Pedro Pa∣checo; my people understand these are his lodg∣ings; and, last night, he wounded a gentleman in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Don Pedro Pacheco!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off.
SP.P: Ay, ay; you know him well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I knew a sister of his, who had those lodg∣ings; but, as you may see, she has been gone from them some time.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off.
SP.P: (to his people) Well, have you found any one?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Off.
SP.P: No, nor any thing; there's some mi∣stake, or they have been too cunning for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I assure you, gentlemen, you may credit what I say.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off.
SP.P: Don't tell me of crediting; I have a warrant, and must enquire.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Signor Octavio, a word with you (taking off his hat, and making a low bow to the Officers.) Worthy gentlemen, I beg your pardon (draws Oc∣tavio aside.) What are you doing with these hell hounds here? Arn't you about an affair that I am acquainted with?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: (aside to Don Guzman) I can't tell that, Sir; I am endeavouring to serve a friend of mine, who has had a rencounter—

SP.SPEAKER: D Guz.
SP.P: I know what you are going to say—the Duke of Medina; is not it so? You understand me. I'll put an end to all this in a minute for you. Who do you look for here, Mr. Alguazil?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Off.
SP.P: A gentleman, call'd Don Pedro Pacheco.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: You know me, don't you?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off.
SP.P: Yes, sure, very well, Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well then, upon my credit, do you mark me, that Don Pedro you look for, is not here; I knew him when he was a child, no higher than my cane; and he has been in Constantinople these three quarters of a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: In Italy you mean, Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P:
In Italy, so he has; I thought he had been among the Turks; but it's the same thing. Here's a couple of doubloons for you, Mr. Algua∣zil: give him two doubloons Octavio. I am sorry to see officers of justice, who should be characters
of respect, and reverence, made laughing stocks of; you have been abused by somebody here, in order to laugh at you; so get about your business, as fast as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Off.
SP.P: To be sure, Don Guzman, since you say the gentleman is not here, we'll take your word. Come along, comrades.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, Octavio.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I desired you to give him a couple of doubloons, Octavio, because you may get them from Don Pedro again.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I find then, Sir, your nephew has—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I know what you are going to say; yes, my nephew has told me all, but not a word to any one else in our house; if my daughter was to hear it, she would fall into fits, she was so fond of her brother, and is so fond of her cousin: besides, being of a tender and delicate disposition, which she in∣herits from her mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: But, pray, Sir, don't you suppose that Don Ferdinand might be mistaken, in imagining he saw Don Carlos, the gentleman who was so unfortunate as to kill your son?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why, I'm afraid so, I'm afraid so, in∣deed, my dear friend: but don't talk to me of that, because it makes me melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I have received a letter this morning, from Don Pedro, to desire I would endeavour to lett these apartments: I don't know how to proceed, but I fancy the best way will be, to put a bill upon the outside door.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why, I am come to talk to you about that; my nephew has received a letter from him too. I suppose you would give this tenement a bargain, to any one, that would take it off your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: To be sure, Sir, on an occasion like this—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P:
You would be glad to take any thing
you could get; isn't that what you were going to say? Why, you're in the right; and I should be sorry, Don Pedro, who is a neighbour's child, re∣ceived any injury by his civility to us: so, if twenty dollars a month will be a sufficient rent, I will e'en hire the premisses for my own use, and take posses∣sion directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Surely, Sir, twenty dollars are too little.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, but consider, it's doing the young man a favour, and I put myself to some inconve∣nience: besides, I won't give a half-penny more.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Then, Sir, it is needless to dispute.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: How many rooms are there?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Will you see them?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No, it is not the first time I have been here; besides, I settled with my nephew how the thing was to be, before I came out.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I suppose, Sir, you intend entering to day?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: You think belike, seeing my family in the house, would prevent further enquiries, and satisfy the Police, that Don Pedro—

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: I really think, Sir, that, as your chief motive for taking the apartment, is to serve Don Pedro, the sooner you and your family come into it, the better.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I am of that opinion too, and as very luckily my time is just up where I now lodge, and I want some larger rooms, in consequence of my daughter's marriage, which I shall shortly celebrate; I am this moment preparing to move the furniture from one place to the other, and shall send to you for the key, within this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: You will oblige me, Don Guzman, by charging yourself with the key now; for having a small vineyard near town, I have shut up my place below, and sent all my servants, men and women, to work there.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: And you want to go yourself, is it not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P:
I thought of setting off before this, and
staying for the remainder of the week, had not Don Pedro's affairs detained me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, well, go your ways, and mind your business; I'll take he key from you. (looking round, as he is going out.) Let me see; was it twenty, or fifteen dollars a month, we talked of?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Twenty, Sir, you offered.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Twenty! Are you sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Oct.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, but that's too much for bare walls; however, my nephew shall speak to Don Pedro, about some abatement.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Carlos, Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (loking after them▪) They are gone out again, and have locked the door upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Did you hear all that has passed, Muskato?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, every word of it; but don't grow desperate upon that account, things are no so bad as we expected; this is a respite at least, if not a reprieve.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: A respite! Has not Don Guzman taken this house over my head, and am I not by that means in the hands of my most cruel and avowed nemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, but he does not know you are in his hands; and by some fortunate means or other, you may, perhaps, contrive to slip thro' his fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: To compleat my misfortune to, the merchant below is gone out, with his family, and has shut up his doors; so that my retreat is stopped that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: For my part, I'm stupified; my crusts are gone, my hunger remains, and I could drink aqua∣fortis.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: But, come, Muskato, never let us be conquered by the persecutions of fate; let us try if we cannot help ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: You may try, what you will; for my part, I can do nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: By forcing the lock of the door, we may get out before our enemy returns, more effectually to stop our passage: I know the danger of shewing myself at this hour in the streets, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, nothing is so dangerous as stay∣ing here; if we can get out; so, pray let us force the door; I have broke a lock before now, upon a less justifiable occasion; and if you'll lend me your assistance, I'll do my endeavour to master this—(goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I wish I had some better weapon than the hilt of my sword; however, what we want in proper instruments, we must endeavour to supply with strength. (going to follow Muskato.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (returning in a fright.) Quick, Sir, quick; get back to the stair-case.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Don Guzman's people are in the house; come here, and hide yourself, and ask no questions (get behind the pannel.)

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Beatrice, and Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And so, these are the lodgings we are in such a hurry to leave our old one's for?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Ay; how do you like them?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Like them, not at all; I never saw such a battered barrack in my days; who could build the dog-hole? In the first place, that door has not common sense in it; then the stairs are the wrong way, and so steep, and narrow, that they are like a ladder to get into a cock loft: and the windows! mercy on us, what pidgeon holes; and a mile and a half from the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Ay, there's the fault; you want to be gap∣ing and staring into the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
Lazarillo, run to the old gentleman, and tell him, if he has not already signed the agree∣ment, he must by no means take this house, till the landlord engages to alter the door, turn the
stair-case the contrary way, and enlarge the windows.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Pray, Mrs. Beatrice, carry your own mes∣sages, I have something else to do. A load of fur∣niture will be below presently, which must be placed in the apartments, within this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I hear a coach; sure it is not my lady al∣ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: But it is tho'; you had better tell her you don't like the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: So I shall, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: I don't doubt it; you have assurance suffi∣cient—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Assurance, indeed! I love you for that with all my heart.—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Marcella.
DIV2.P: La', Ma'am, you are in great haste; I did not ex∣pect to see you these three hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: I set out to oblige my father; nothing would satisfy him, but I must come directly, to see the apartments, and dispose of the furniture accord∣ing to my own fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Furniture, Ma'am! I'm sure it's a pity to put any into them; if the kennel was mine, I should think of nothing but pulling it down, and selling the rubbish to the best bidder.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Mrs. Beatrice is difficult to please, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So she is indeed, Lazarillo; the building looks very well on the outside, and, as far as I can perceive, promises to be very convenient within.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, if hounds were to live in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Marc.
SP.P: My father tells me, Lazarillo, that it is to please your master, he takes these lodgings; and I suppose it is by his desire that we come to them so suddenly. Do you know the reason of Don Ferdi∣nand's extraordinary attachment?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Why, Ma'am, I'm generally pretty well acquainted with my master's secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I beg your pardon; I did not know it was any secret, or I should not have asked.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Oh, Ma'am there's no secret; that is to say, no absolute secret: but, as far as this here, Ma'am, the air and situation, I believe—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: In short, Ma'am, Signor Lazarillo is a per∣son who seldom chuses to seem ignorant of any thing.—Did your master ever tell you why he liked these lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: I can't say he ever did.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Then you can give my lady no satisfaction as to her question.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Well, Mrs. Beatrice, I did not speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Never mind her, Lazarillo, but go and take care of those things I brought in the coach.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, Beatrice!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Ay, Ma'am, here I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pity me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Bless my soul, Ma'am, for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I feel myself very unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: O fye, Ma'am, to tell me so, on the eve of your marriage, as it were.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis the thought of that makes me me∣lancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Is it, indeed? I'm sure then, Ma'am, you and I are of very different dispositions—I wish I was going to be married; the deuce a thing shou'd I think of, but what wou'd make me very glad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How, Beatrice! suppose you were going to set out upon a journey, which presented you with the most beautiful prospect; but, on the first ad∣vances you made, you found yourself on the brink of a precipice, what would you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: A very great precipice, do you mean; or, only a little sort of a declivity?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pshaw! I'm not in a jesting humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, but, Ma'am, let me understand you.—You ask me, if I was going to set out on a journey, which presented me with the most beau∣tiful prospect; and, on the first advances I made, I found myself on the brink of a precipice—what I wou'd do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why then, Ma'am, I'll tell you—In case it was not a very ugly precipice indeed, I wou'd muster up all my strength—shut my eyes, so—and give a great jump.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I told you before, that it was no subject to turn into ridicule. In short, Beatrice, my cousin, Don Ferdinand—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (stopping her mistress.) He's here, Ma'am.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: How happy am I, to arrive at a moment when you pronounce my name!—I have the plea∣sure to know then, that you do sometimes con∣descend to think of me in my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I know not whether that should give you pleasure, or not.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: To live in your remembrance, must do so; we naturally think of those we love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: We sometimes think too little of those we ought to love.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Can that cruel reflection be design'd for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: I am at a loss to answer you, perhaps—but I had just begun to talk to Beatrice, when your coming into the room, interrupted me—I will take up the discourse again, if you please; and finish what I was going to say to her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am content.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Stand there then, Sir; and we'll proceed in our d scourse, as if you were fifty miles off—Come, Ma'am, begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
I say then, Beatrice, my cousin, Don Fer∣dinand,
no doubt, imagines that marriage is a dis∣pensation from the subaltern duties, exacted by com∣plaisance, since he already begins to fail in those marks of tenderness and regard, I expected to find from him—he forgets that love is nourished by at∣tention; and, that the slightest negligence, kills it—Yesterday evening I went to the Prado—Don Fer∣dinand stayed behind—I was in danger of my life—Don Ferdinand, indeed, came to my assistance; but not till I had been previously rescued by another—I got home terrified and disordered—Don Ferdinand immediately went out, and left me—I am willing to excuse this behaviour; but, at the same time, I can∣not help saying to myself, how will he treat me when I am his wife, if he uses me thus, while he calls me his mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Ah, dear Marcella, did you know how uneasy you make me by this kind of discourse—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And why uneasy?—I did not address my∣self to you—what I spoke, was said to Beatrice—and you need take no notice of it, as you need not be supposed to overhear.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
That's right, Ma'am—and to let you know another thing, Sir, you are not to take the words out of my mouth—my lady spoke to me; and it's my part to answer—and here's the way I do it—I suppose, Ma'am, Don Ferdinand is like the rest of his sex; who, for the most part, follow women as they hunt hares and foxes: when the animal's catched, the sport is over.—I once had a sweetheart myself, Ma'am, that used to call me his queen, and his goddess; and, one day, he wanted to kill him∣self for me; but, when he found I was willing to let him, he soon convinced me, he was not in earnest. I remember, he used to compare my eyes to dia∣monds; and my lips to rubies; and my teeth to pearl; and my neck to alabaster: and he used to say, his heart was set a▪fire; and that the steel of my
beauty, had struck against the flint of his inclination; and a great deal of stuff, in that way.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Stuff, indeed, Beatrice!—But your lady will do me the justice to confess, that from the first moment she vouchsafed to listen to my pretensions, I never gave into those ridiculous hyperboles, which accompany the declarations of ordinary lovers: such can only be of use to charm vulgar minds. The only eloquence to persuade a mind, formed like my Marcella's, is sincerity; and, I always thought, the best way to acquire her esteem, was to convince her that she possessed mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, will you be so good as to repeat that over again; if it is not the prettiest thing I ever heard in my life; I believe you took it from some novel though.—Come, Ma'am, give him your hand to kiss, and tell him you are friends with him.—Look you there, Sir, I knew it—There's nothing does with us, like a little talk.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer,
SP.P: (Kissing Marcella's hand, which she gives him.) Your father, my dear, is determined to have our wedding a public one; and Saturday next, he assures me, shall be the happy day. Just as I left home, a good many of your things were brought, which I have ordered to be sent here, with some boxes of rich wine, and foreign sweetmeats, for the ball I intend to give a select number of our friends, to-morrow night. In the mean time, I'll step back to the old lodgings, to see things properly taken care of.—Lazerillo, bring up those parcels.—Examine them, my dear.—And you, Mrs. Beatrice, will not find yourself forgotten.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice, and then Lazarillo, who enters with candles, and is afterwards followed by two servants, who bring in a table, and set it against the pannel where Don Carlos and Muskato are shut up; they also bring in two chairs, some cases of wine, and boxes, some of which they place upon the table.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
O then, there's something for me! Laza∣rillo,
make haste up with the things.—I suppose it's the new gown he promis'd to give me; and that your mantua-maker took measure of me for. I long to see it.—Lazarillo, I say, will you be all day?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Coming, Mrs. Beatrice, coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why don't you make haste then?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: It's impossible to make haste enough for impatient people.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Have not you something that your master gave you for me, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: I have something for every body—but that's your bundle, I believe—(gives her a parcel, which she immediately opens)—Here, comrades, bring in the table, and set it yonder, that I may put these things upon it; and then bring up the boxes, and cases of wine that you'll find in the hall; quick, quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (Having display'd her gown on a chair.) Dear madam, look here; upon my life, it's very pretty; and every thing complete; a veil, and a petticoat, and lined throughout with silk. I have a good mind to try it on now—(going to unpin herself)—Do you think it will become me, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
