SP.P: Your head runs upon nothing but your dress.—Follow me, to see the condition of the other rooms.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: We are going back for more things, Mrs. Beatrice; you'll please to take care of what we leave behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: O stay then, till I shut the doors—(crosses the stage, to shut the opposite door; returning, she stops a moment at the door where she goes out, to admire the gown)—Well, I swear and vow, it's one of the genteelest things I ever saw in my life.—I wish, however, there had been a little more puffing upon the sleeves.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Carlos, Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (Speaking, as he puts up the pannel.) I will go out.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Zounds, Sir, don't tell me; as good be hang'd, as famish'd—(Perceiving the table that has been put against the pannel, which prevents his coming forward)—Hey-day! what have we here?—They have rais'd a buttrass against our wooden wall—(Putting his hand among the things on the table, throws some of them down)—Bow, wow, wow!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What are you doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Making a noise.—How shall I remove these impediments?—(Attempting to push the table from him, he overturns it)—Oh Lord! oh Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Death and hell! are you bent on our ruin?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir, don't swear.—(Coming out.)—Damn the table, I did but just touch it.—However, no body has heard.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Come in here.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Presently.—(Taking up, and opening a box.)—What have we here! Sweetmeats!—(Eating a piece)—excellent, i'faith;—and here are cakes—and here's chocolate—(Stuffing his pockets)—and here's—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (Coming forward too.) What have you got yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: I'll tell you by and by.—(Breaking open one of the cases)—Wine, wine, wine!—(Falling upon his knees, and looking back on his master.)—This is the short way of drawing a cork.—(Knocks off the head of the flask.)—Sir, my service to you.—(Drinks.)—Will you pledge me?—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Why, since you have—

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Take a large gulp; it will do you good.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: They'll certainly come upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P:
(Eating, and speaking with his mouth full.) Lord, what an admirable blessing did Nature bestow upon man, when she gave him a good stomach—Where's the bottle?—(Drinks again.)—You had better take t'other tiff, Sir; and if you'll follow my
advice, you'll pick a bit, for I'm sure you must be devilish hungry—Here's a charming root of eringo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Muskato, let us think of our situation. What shall we do here, we are yet undiscover'd; shall we wait the return of night, and then force our way out of the house, at all events whatever?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Why, Sir, Zounds! my stomach was so empty when I drank, that the wine's getting into my head. I say, Sir, as to the force you talk of—If your friends and family cou'd be appriz'd of your situation, and design; but as the matter stands, Sir, I don't think we shall be able to make our escape by violence.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: We can't pick our way thro' the walls then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: No, Sir, I wish we cou'd; but I'll tell you, Sir, I think one of us might get out unnoticed, by means of a disguise: now suppose I take upon me this disguise, make my escape, inform your friends where you are, and have 'em ready—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: But how?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: You see that gown there, and the veil and things along with it; I'll carry it into our re∣pository, dress myself ala demoiselle, watch my op∣portunity when it is dark, and I warrant, get clear, without any suspicion; I'll take the gown, Sir, the think is determin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: 'Sdeath here is somebody coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Is there (gathering the cloaths under his arm) lay hold of that bottle then, and follow me to my toilette.

DIV2.STAGE: Beatrice, Marcella.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (enters a little before her mistress, singing; but seeing the condition the room is in, she turns her song by degrees, into a scream, and runs out again) Fal, lal, lal, lal, lal, lal,—Oh—h—h—h Ma'am, Ma'am, come here and see what has happen'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (entering) What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: The devil's the matter, for I'm sure he has been here; did you ever see the like of this, all the things turn'd topsy turvey, and half of them broke to pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Who has been in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I don't know, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This seems to have been done on purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (looking about, screams) Ah—h!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How now!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: My new gown, Ma'am, where's my new gown that I left here when we went out, did not you see me spread it upon the chair with the other things?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And now it's stol'n and gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Call some body?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo, Lopez, Sancho!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This is very odd.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo—I will have my gown.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Guzman and Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: There's always a rout, and a racket, wherever this girl is—What are you after now, Mrs. Fidget?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: We have been robb'd, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Robb'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo, did not you give me my things in this room, and did you not see me leave them here when you went out again?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Ay; well, what then, suppose I did?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, you must answer for them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: And who is to answer for all this pretty work, I wou'd be glad to know? Why, you silly baggage, you, did you think your frippery was stuff'd into the boxes, and wine-cases, that you have broke them to pieces?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It was not I.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Who, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Old nick, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Gad, I have a good mind to lay my cane across your shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Speak to him, Ma'am, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, it is something very extraordinary—We left the things here in good order, a little while ago, and this moment that we came into the room again, we found them in the condition you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: some dog got in, I suppose, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat,
SP.P: Ay, some dog upon two legs: Dogs in Spain, don't drink wine, and eat sweetmeats, nor steal gowns: indeed, Sir, you ought to pay me for my things, if I don't get them again.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I pay for them, hussey! do you think I stole your dab of a gown?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Some of your servants did:

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Do you suspect me, Mrs. Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Hey dey! do you know where you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Beatrice, have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I will have my gown.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Come, child, you shall go with me to the other lodgings, where we will dine, and after dinner return hither, by which time most of the furniture will be mov'd: and do you here, let those things be taken away, and this room set to rights immediately; and if you find this slattern's trumpery in any hole, or corner, lay them by for her. (turn's, going out)

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo, you certainly stole my things.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: I stole your things! damme, if you say so again—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Take that, you impudent jackanapes (gives him a box on the ear.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ay, Ay, before my face, and behind my back too; no respect to me on either side (beating them out before him with his cane) I'll teach you, you impudent vermin, to bite, and scratch in my presence.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A parlour belonging to a monastery; with an iron grate in the back scene; thro' which is seen the chapel, a lamp burning, &c.
Aurora enters alone.
DIV2.P: HOW painful is a state of suspence! and what a night, and day, have I passed!—When I reflect on the situation in which I left Don Carlos, I am half distracted—Suppose he has endeavoured to make his escape; and, in the attempt, fallen into the hands of justice: or, suppose he still remains shut up in the house?—Will he not, in either case, condemn me, as the contriver of his misfortune?—I have prevailed upon the portress of this convent, where my brother has confined me, to let Leonarda out; she has taken with her a master-key, which was providentially in the trunk sent hither with my cloaths—If Carlos is yet in the house, she will give him that, and he may release himself as soon as it is night—If he is already gone, I shall, at least, be so far satisfied, as to know it—And, probably, if he has been seized—
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Leonarda.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: (speaking without.) Very well, mother; very well: it is the strongest I could get; and I hope it will please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Here she comes—Oh, Leonarda!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, I'm here at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I thought you would never return. How could you, knowing my impatience and distess, keep me so long on the rack!—Well, what of Don Carlos?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Of Don Carlos, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why not a great deal, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: How, not a great deal?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Is there any one can overhear what we say?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Nay, but look to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I tell you there is no one: speak, and ease me of my anxiety.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I can't be easy till I have shut that door.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Was ever such a tormenting creature!—Will you make haste, and tell me what you have done in the affair I sent you upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Well, Ma'am, I am going to tell you, if you'll have patience, and give me time to recollect myself a little—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Take time.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why, Ma'am, as soon as you gave me the key, and I got out of the convent here, I made the best of my way to our street, considering with my∣self how I cou'd come to the door of the house, and open it, if possible, without being observed by the people of Octavio, the wine-merchant; for you know, Ma'am, the more secret I did the thing, the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: No doubt on't. Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Well; and so, Ma'am, going along, as I tell you, at the turning of the lane, before you come to the Jacobine's Church, who should I meet, but Signor Octavio himself, mounted upon his mule, just going out of town: you may be sure, we stopp'd to speak to one another; and he asked me, if you had seen your brother: No, Sir, says I, not since last night. Well, says he, give my service to your lady, and tell her, she may be quite easy about him, for Don Guzman has taken your house—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (With precipitation.) What Don Guzman?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P:
Don Guzman de Ribbera, Ma'am: and he,
and his family, have been in it, since eleven o'clock this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don Guzmàn de Ribbera!

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am: and so, after hearing that, you know it was in vain for me to think of going near it.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: And so you don't know whether Don Car∣los has made his escape, or not? or what is become of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: How shou'd I, Ma'am, unless I was a witch!—But, I take it for granted, he's in the house still, unless he has made his escape, without any one's discovering him:—for to be sure, Ma'am, if Signor Octavio had known any thing about him, he wou'd have mentioned it; and I put him a great many leading questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: And where have you been all this time, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Been, Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Ay, where you have been upwards of these hours, that you were gone from hence?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why, Ma'am, I went to see a cousin of mine, that's lately come to town.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Wretched, insensible creature!—Then I am still left in the same cruel uncertainty!—But, at any rate, I am determined to know the worst:—Give me the key, and your veil, and call the portress of the convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Dear Ma'am, where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Ask no questions; you that go to see a cousin, while you know I am waiting for you; and think every moment an hour—

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Lord, Ma'am, you need not be angry; I shou'd not have stayed so long, but there was a christening, and they wanted a gossip.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, and call the portress.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: She's here, Ma'am.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter an old Nun.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Oh, mother, mother, if ever you knew what it was to feel but for yourself, pity, and assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: What's the matter with her, what's she crying for?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why, mother, you remember the gentle∣man, that my lady told you of, that we left lock'd up in the house last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: No, I don't call it to mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Yes, you know you let me out this after∣noon, to enquire after him, and give him a key.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Well, and is that what she's crying for?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Lord, mother, no; you won't listen to me—I went to give him the key, but I cou'd not do it, for another gentleman had taken the house, and was gone to live in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: O stay, what! you gave the key to another gentleman, and he took it out of the house—

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: No; another gentleman took the house: a muzzy old fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I shall go mad I think—Mother I throw myself upon your goodness, and have a request to make to you, which unless you grant, you must expect to see me commit some fatal violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Must I truly; I am glad you have told me so, for I will call up the house directly—Take her bodkin from her, her scissars, and her garters. and ring the bell: Saint Francis be my guard, you are desperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Well, I may be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: You must fast, and pray, and we'll send for a father confessor for you—I have had great relief in former days from a father confessor myself, a worthy good man he was, a bare-footed brother of the order of St. Dominick, who administered comfort to this whole convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Well, but listen to my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Dear mother, you have been so kind as to let my maid out, but she miscarried in the design she went upon—The life of a gentleman is at stake; and shou'd any sinister accident happen to him, I shall think myself accountable for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: You both confuse me so, that I don't know what I am doing—I am quite in amaze now; what were you saying to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I want you to open the door, and let me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Don't ask me to do that again.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I promise you faithfully I will return in an hour; and I shall not be ungrateful for your kind∣ness; you know I am not profess'd, nor can I be be left here as a prisoner, having committed no crime; besides, you may oblige me without fear, as the Abbess is confin'd to her bed, and all the sisterhood retired but ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: But what do you want to go out for?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: My lady has told you already.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: No she has'nt.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Yes, mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Lord, Ma'am, you are not going to ex∣plain yourself again, I hope; you know she never remembers a word that's said to her two minutes after it's spoken; and I suspect she has been tasting the cordial I brought her, which has not help'd to quicken her apprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: I think I shou'd know what you want to go abroad for; besides, if it shou'd be discovered that I gave you such liberty, I shou'd be made to do penance—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: It never can be discover'd—Good mother have confidence in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Well, come, I will have confidence in you for once—I know I'm an old fool, but I can't help taking pity upon a creature of our years.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: But dear, Ma'am, may I be so bold as to ask the question?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I have no time to answer any thing now—Go into my chamber, bolt the door on the inside, and stay up till I come back.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I will, Ma'am, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Come, mother, open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Open the door, my child, why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Why, aren't you going to let my lady out?

SP.SPEAKER: Nun.
SP.P: Oh, ay, that's true.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I can't tell what scheme my lady has in her head, but I know if she does not contrive to get out of this convent very soon, for good and all, I shall give her warning; for I cannot, nor I will not live in a place where one never has the sight of a man, so there's the short and the long of it.

DIV2.STAGE: Scene changes to the room in Don Guzman's house, where Don Carlos, and Muskato, are hid behind the pannel. The walls, which in the last act appeared bare, are now covered with tapestry, and the chamber otherwise furnish'd. Lazarillo carrying a table, Beatrice entering before him with a looking∣glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Here, awkwardness, here; set the table on this side, while I go and place this looking-glass on my lady's toilet.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: And why on that side? I think it's better on this; and here I'll set it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It shan't stay there.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Then you shall lug it where you like, yourself; for plague fetch me if I stretch a finger to move it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (lays the glass on the table, and removes it.) I never knew such a rude, disobliging, unmannerly ur as you are, in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Ay, to be sure, it's much better now.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (calling.) Lopez, bring the candles.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Pray, Mrs. Beatrice, how soon is my master and your lady to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (to Lopez, who brings the candles.) Now, go, and do as I ordered you in the other rooms. (setting the glass up between the candles, and viewing herself.) What did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I asked you, how soon our young folks were to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (still viewing herself) If you want to know, it's a question you ought to ask them.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I must, faith; for it will be necessary for me to get my things, and look a little about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What! and so you don't intend to stay with Don Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Oh! damn it, no; it would not do for me at all. Service with a single gentleman, well and good; but married families are hell and the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Do you intend to list for a soldier then; or turn barber; or what? 'Tis dangerous being out of place; I have known several of your fraternity come to an untimely end by it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And, pray, what do you think of the situation of a discarded abigail, mounted up three pair of stairs into a back garret, to live upon her savings? But, to tell you the truth, I am afraid to stay with Don Ferdinand, lest, as valets are apt to ape their masters, I should be tempted to imitate him; and, as he had married your mistress, the devil might put it into my head to marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (Turning quite round, and surveying him with an air of contempt.) What is the matter with this glass! It always makes me look browner than any other in the house. (wiping it with her hand∣kerchief, and going from it in a minuet step.) We shall have a ball here tomorrow evening: I suppose the company will desire to see me dance an allemande, or a andango, or something.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Come, you have enjoyed it long enough (whips the glass from her;) now let me look at my∣self a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo, give me the glass.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (viewing himself) Dam'me, if I don't think people look very well in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Did ever one see such an impertinent! Give me the glass, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Come and kiss me for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I'll see you hanged first.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Then you shan't have it (dancing, with the glass in his hand, as she had done before it.) Tol de rol, lol, lol.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Upon my life and soul (going to take the glass from him, she turns of a sudden, and runs out on the other side.) Lord! here's Don Guzman, and your master!

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Here, Beatrice, take the glass (lays it on the table.) The devil!—

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, Don Ferdinand, and two servants, who come in, and go out again immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I have been at the Duke of Medina's; and I find his wounds are not so bad as I at first apprehended; though he is still in danger. The report, however, of Don Pedro being the person who assaulted him, rather gains ground; and I hear the police is still making strict enquiry after him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Nay, some officers have, as I under∣stand, been seen, within these two hours, walking backwards and forwards, before this house, and looking at it very inquisitively.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Then, belike, they still suspect that Don Pedro is in it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: So it should seem.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P:
And we may have a visit from them in the night, perhaps, when we least desire their com∣pany. Is not that what you were going to say? Egad, I am very much obliged to you for the hint; and I'll strive to prevent them; for, I should not like to be rous'd from my sleep, and get a cold
that, perhaps, might kill me. I want somebody (a servant enters.) Come hither, you Sir. Go to the Conde de Lemos, governor of Madrid; his pa∣lace is hard by; give my respects, and tell his ex∣cellency, I shall be much obliged to him, if he will order me directly a couple of centinels to stand at my door. Tell him I shall want them for two, or three days, till I have married my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well but, Sir, a couple of centinels!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ay; is not it a good thought? I war∣rant the officers won't venture to molest us when they see these gentry; and I know the Conde de Lemos will be ready to do me any honour, our houses being related.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But won't my cousin be surprized? I fancy, Sir, we had better trust her with the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: It must not be, foolish; I tell you, I know her constitution; it might bring her to a sick-bed, and prevent your being married to her these three months; besides, is there any thing more common than to have centinels at the door, upon occasion of publick weddings? (To a servant, who appears) Well, have you fitted up the next rooms for my nephew, as I order'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No, Sir! and why so, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Because, Sir, Mrs. Beatrice bid us not▪

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Mrs. Beatrice!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; she said Don Ferdinand's cham∣ber would be better at the other end of the gallery; so we are getting it ready there.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Are you so, Sir? Then I desire you will go immediately, and get it ready where I or∣dered you. I protest this is quite abominable; Mrs. Beatrice, indeed! In direct opposition to my commands!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P:
I have not seen Don Pedro since yester∣day, Sir▪ and, as he has given me an intimation
where he is concealed, I will now, with your per∣mission, step to him for a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What! to night?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: He will think it unkind, I imagine, if I neglect to enquire after him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, well, go then; you'll be back to supper?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I shall make no delay, but just to see how he is disposed of.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Guzman,
SP.P: And now that we have got pretty well over the hurry of moving, let me see what I have to do tomorrow. In the first place, early in the morning, to go to my lawyers, to desire them to be here precisely at eleven o'clock, to settle the business of my daugh∣ter's marriage. Secondly, to go to Father Bartolin, our parish priest, to let him know, we shall be with him at nine o'clock on Saturday—Saturday! Ay, Sa∣turday, that's the day after to-morrow: Thursday, Friday, Saturday—then I have something else to do: let me consider! To go to my lawyer; to go to the parish priest; to go—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Beatrice and Lazarillo, on opposite sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (as loud as she can bawl.) Lazarillo!

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: (answering in the same tone.) Here!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (clapping his fingers to his ears.) How now! What the plague's the matter with you both, have you a mind to break the drums of my ears?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: What do you scream so for, Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Scream! One and the other of you, have screamed me almost deaf. What do you want, tur∣bulence?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, I'm surprized at you. How can you have the idea of making the best room in your house a bed-chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Because I like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, Sir, it will be shocking.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What's that to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Besides, I suppose Don Ferdinand will re∣move to my lady's chamber, in a night or two.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ha, now you have got that in your head; and who bid you suppose about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, it's no business of mine, to be sure, if you have a mind to turn the house upside don, only I love to set people right, and see things done properly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, but my nephew chose that room particularly, and I think it's most proper he should have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Why, so I told Mrs. Beatrice, Sir. I said, my master had made particular choice of that room.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Very well then, let his bed be put in it; but remember, Sir, it's done by no order of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No, why should it? I know of no right you have to order any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: But I am sure, it will be the most absurd, ridiculous, vulgar—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: A messenger from the governor of Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: The Conde de Lemos, governor of Madrid, presents his compliments to Don Guzman de Rib∣bera; and desires to let him know, that he grants his request with regard to the centinels, which shall be posted at his door within this half hour. And, if Don Guzman will inform the Conde, on what day his daughter is to be married, he will not only send his equipages to attend the cavalcade to church, but himself, and his countess, will come to be present at the performance of the ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
Return Don Guzman's compliments to the Conde de Lemos; he is extremely obliged to his excellency for the honour he designs him, and shall be very glad of his company, and that of the coun∣tess: my young lady is to be married on Saturday; but, if any thing should happen between rhis and
that, to alter the day, Don Guzman will take care to give my lord governor timely notice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: So, so! how's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Is not that right, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What do you think? Hold, young man, don't go 'till you get the whole of your business: have you any thing more to say to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, Sir, unless you chuse to ask his excel∣lency to the ball.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why, you most impudent, audacious creature, how dare you take the liberty to give an answer to a message sent to me, in my presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, I did it to save you trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I protest before heaven, I never heard such assurance in my life. (turning to the messenger.) My respects to the governor, Sir, and I will wait upon his excellency directly, to thank him for his great favour to me. (the messenger goes out.) I be∣lieve there never was your fellow for impertinence, since the world begun. But why should I be sur∣prized at this, when I am told, you give out all over the neighbourhood, that I am going to marry you?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ay, you may well laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I never gave out any such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Don't lie, for I can prove it upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I say then, Sir, I never did; for the thing was first mentioned to me: and, isn't it common enough, when a genteel likely girl lives in the house with a gentleman, for people to talk?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, I shan't dispute the matter with you, now. Go, take the coach, and fetch your young lady home, she's at her aunt's. And you, Lazarillo, take one of those candles, and set it in the next room, that your master may find things ready at his return. (to Beatrice.) Why don't you go where I bid you?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I'm settling myself, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (going out with a candle.) Ha! ha! ha! marry!—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What's the matter with you? I promise you I don't know whether I would take the old fellow, if he would have me; so he need not make himself uneasy.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, and then Aurora, veiled.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: A paltry, dirty baggage; to give out that I was going to marry her; there never was such a thought entered into my head. (Don Guzman walking up the stage, sees her as he comes down.)
Hey dey! Who have we here? Who is it that comes into the house this way without knocking! Is there no body in the way to shew people?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don't be offended, Signor, at the liberty an unfortunate woman has taken, upon seeing your door open; I implore a moment's refuge.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I have the misfortune to be the wife of the most jealous, and suspicious of mankind, who is at the same time the most cruel. Upon a person's looking after me in the street, just now, he took something into his head, drew his poinard, and was going to strike me—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: O for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I got from him, and made my escape in hither; but he is lurking about, and I am afraid, when I go out again—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What can I do for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: You seem a man of courage and authority, Sir; I intreat you to go down, into the street, and speak to him not to misuse me; you will easily know him, he is in a red cloak, and wears a gold laced hat, with a black feather.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I'll go down, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P:
In the mean time, Sir, permit me to remain here; and, as I am a person of some distinction in the world, I beg you will not suffer your people to
come about me, 'till your humanity has rescued me from the danger—

SP.SPEAKER: D▪ Guz.
SP.P: Sp into that chamber, Madam, where you will find light, and nobody shall molest you. I warrant I'll give a good account of your jealous pate, and if words won't do, rougher means shall.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman leads Aurora to the door, and then taking up the candle, goes out on the opposite side, which leaves the stage dark. Don Carlos imme∣diately raises the moveable pannel, and comes out with Muskato, who is disguised in woman's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: It is now quite dark; and you may, if ever, escape without being seen; as for myself, I'll wait with patience, determined to brave every thing till your return.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I don't know what's the matter with me, Sir; I am damnably frightened.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: As soon as you have brought my friends together in the street, the signal is to be a pistol; which, when I hear discharged, I will instantly rush out, and force my passage to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Ay, Sir; but the grand matter is my get∣ting out.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Farewell; at any rate don't let your ap∣prehensions confound you.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Carlos retires, leaving Muskato in the middle of the stage; at the same time Aurora appears at the door of the room, into which she had been conducted by Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don Guzman's gone; and all is dark; this is the moment to find Don Carlos: Assist me love; and, if he be yet here—

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Eh! eh! eh! (coughing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Hah! what figure's that standing in the middle of the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P:
I have neither courage nor strength, to move back, or forward. This is a cursed scheme
of mine; I wish I had never thought of it; it will bring me to the gallows, I'm sure; then they'll hang me in woman's cloaths; which will be a double shame and mortification.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: It moves this way; was ever any thing so unlucky? I must retire a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Come, courage; it is but making the ef∣fort; if I can but get down stairs, I am safe enough; (going towards the door, sees Don Guzman.) then there's an end of me; tried, condemned, and exe∣cuted. The old man!

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman re-enters with the candle; and, seeing Muskato veil'd, and in woman's cloaths, takes him for Aurora, whom he had left.

SP.SPEAKER: D Guz.
SP.P: Come, madam, you may take your way, without the least apprehension; I have looked all about the door, and sent my servants up and down the street, and no such person as you describe was to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (aside) What is he talking of?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Apparently, finding you were got into an asylum, and knowing it was my house, your husband made off: but, give me your hand, ma'am, I am going abroad myself, and will lead you to whatever place of safety you think proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: What's all this! Sure, if ever there was an angel with a beard and wrinkles, this is he.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Poor soul, how she trembles; fear no∣thing, ma'm; in committing yourself to my charge you are perfectly secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (curtsying, and in a squeaking voice) I am much obliged to you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Her tears almost choak her voice. Will you have any cordial to refresh you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (curtsying again) No thank you, Sir; take me out.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I will; come along, and don't be frightened, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: A good voyage to us; this is the finest ac∣cident—

DIV2.STAGE: Aurora, and Don Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Now is my time. Good Heaven! how I tremble! I am almost afraid to approach the place (knocking at the pannel, Don Carlos lifts it up.) Sir; Don Carlos; Sir: merciful Heaven! he's here still.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Not yet stirred from hence, Muskato! What are you thinking of? Take my sword, if you are afraid, and I will defend myself as well as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don't you know me then?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Donna Aurora!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I was obliged to leave you here last night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Obliged to leave me!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: It is too long a story to tell you now. I sent Leonarda as soon I could, this morning, to bring you this master-key; but, when she came, she found Don Guzman had taken the house, and was afraid to enter: doubtful of what was become of you, and, fearing the danger you might be in, I have escaped from a convent, where my brother placed me, resolved to make my way to you through all impediments: there is the key; let yourself out in the dead of night; farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Stay, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Oh, unfortunate! here comes Marcella, the daughter of Don Guzman: I would not for the world be known by her. Get in; get in; there's another woman with her. What shall I do? Any thing's better than meeting them (she retires.)

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Marcella, and Beatrice, with lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What was it you asked Lazarillo, Bea∣trice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, Ma'am, whether his master was at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And what did he say?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What you heard, ma'am, that he was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That he had been gone out about half an hour; was it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, take my fan, and my veil, and ee that my things are got ready in the dressing-room. (Beatrice goes out with the things) A strange unsea∣sonable hour for Don Ferdinand to leave the house, methinks; and just at a time when he knew I was coming home too. I am uneasy; and, sure, not without cause; he cannot but see how cautious I am, by shewing the smallest indifference—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (re-entering, in great agitation, upon her tip∣toes) Ma'am! ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, what now?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Don't make a noise. I have seen such a thing, in Don Ferdinand's chamber; and, I be∣lieve, I have found out the thief too; for I dare swear she stole my gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: She! what she?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: A woman, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: In Don Ferdinand's chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes; as I was going along the passage, I observed the door pushed too; so I popped my head in; and there I saw a woman in a veil. I did not say a word, but came back directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: We'll, see who she is; take the candles.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am; she can't escape us, for the the door's shut at the head of the stairs; so, if she runs round, she must come in here. (they go out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (behind) We will know who you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: That's as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What brings you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I came here to a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Pull off her viel, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Nay, then—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Stop there, a thief!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Follow her, Beatrice.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Carlos, lifting up the pannel, comes out, and then Don Ferdinand enters at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What noise was that! Sure it was Aurora's voice; somebody molests her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Ha! Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: A man.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What man!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: One that will pass without answering questions.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Not while I can oppose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (running in) Save me, Carlos; they pursue me; I shall be discovered, and undone.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Fear nothing (puts on his mask, and draws his sword, just as Marcella and Beatrice enter with lights.) Now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, a mask! (drawing his sword:) robber, and villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (Running out with the light again) Ah! what have we here! Swords, swords, swords!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Beatrice!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (stamping) Lights! here` lights!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (going behind the pannel) Let us retire to the stair-case.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Lights, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nobody shall go out.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No, I'll take care of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Help!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Lights!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Beatrice, Lazarillo, and other servants. Beatrice keeping back with the lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh dear! oh dear! oh dear, is any one murder'd?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Bring in the lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I daren't, I'm afraid to see blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Beatrice, bring in the lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (entering all in a tremble) Oh, let them put up their swords then.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Where is this assassin, this house-breaker?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Where is this shame to her sex?

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Sir, Madam, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: There has been a man here, mask'd—search about.

SP.SPEAKER: Laz.
SP.P: Where shall we search, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Call to the centinels to let nobody out of the house—Follow me; he can't have made his escape.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh, Ma'am, you have let the woman go, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I, let her go!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, it was certainly she that was here this morning; how did she get away?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Don Ferdinand let her pass; but how did she get in here, Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, Ma'am, I have heard say, that there are gangs of these sort of people, who watch when doors are left open, to whip into houses and carry off the goods.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And so you believe this woman—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, Ma'am—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What, do you suppose that the woman was shut up in Don Ferdinand's chamber, in order to rob the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, Ma'am, I don't think that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Did not she say she came to a gentleman too?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And yet you don't know what to make of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, I can't say, Ma'am—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (bursting into tears, and going off) Well, I do; but it does not signify, I am not at all uneasy about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (alone) Stay, hold, I believe there is something in the wind here, that I have not been able to discover: did not she say she came to a gentleman? Yes, she did, sure enough; and she was hid in Don Ferdinand's chamber (pausing) Lord, what a fool I was! I see the affair now, as plain as any thing in the world.

DIV2.TRAILER: THE END OF THE THIRD ACT.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Chamber in Don Guzman's house: Don Ferdinand enters with a letter, followed by Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: AND pray, Sir, who gave you this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: La
SP.P: Why, Sir, nobody gave it to me; that is to say, what you can properly call gave; but just now while you were abroad, and I was brushing your cloaths yonder in the gallery, Mrs. Beatrice bolted out of her lady's chamber; there, says she, there's a letter for your sweet master; 'tis from Donna Marcella, give it him: and with that, Sir, throwing to me, or rather flinging at me, the paper you now hold in your hand, she turn'd upon her heel, and shut the door with a clap, that made the house shake again.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer
SP.P: Let me read it once more, that I may be sure I clearly understand her meaning. “Tho' I am satisfied there are some instances of ill behaviour in your sex, which the delicacy of ours hardly permits us to take notice of; I cannot help telling you, that your bringing an ill woman into my father's house last night, is a proceeding of that monstrous nature, as is neither to be defended, or forgiven. What, while you was under a contract of marriage with his daughter; when the most sacred promise of lasting fidelity! was ready to part from your lips: but I will not animadvert on an action, I cannot think of without horror; I shall only inform you, that there is an end of any farther connection between you and me.”

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And so she concludes, your humble servant Marcella de Ribbera?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Did you ever hear the like of it?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, I can't charge my memory exactly; but for the meaning of the letter, I think it pretty plain.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: D'ye?—Now to me it is utterly inexpli∣cable: was there a woman in the house last night?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why, Sir, the servants say so:—I suppose after Donna Marcella—and from the reports of Mrs. Beatrice—for my own part, I neither saw man nor woman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: A man there was, by all that's sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Very well, Sir, I don't pretend to contradict you; but how did he contrive to slip away from us then? The centinels were posted at the door before you came in; and as the family was awake, and stirring about, I think it hardly possible for him to have got from the chambers to the street, without meeting some one or other of us in his passage.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: The possibility of the thing is clear, by it's having happened. No doubt, a lucky moment favoured his escape; and though the centinels say nobody passed, he might, before they were ap∣prized, have gone out unnoticed by them.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay, that's true too, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But, at any rate, Lazarillo, I am by no means sorry this affair has happened; on the con∣trary, it lets me into some circumstances relative to Donna Marcella's turn of mind, which it is my in∣terest to be acquainted wth; and I am glad to come to a knowledge of them before it is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, and so you ought. Ah! Sir, it is not always your faces full of smiles, and dimples, that cover the kindest hearts, or the best natures; and between ourselves, I have long suspected, that Donna Marcella conceal'd more under hers, than she chose to let appear for the present. A tyger's a tyger, Sir, for all it's pretty spotted skin; and the likeness between the beast, and the Christian, lies in this: as in the animal, a fair outside is the wrapper, or surtout, to a damn'd, growling, fierce disposition; so a lady, though she has a face like an angel, may have a temper worse than a devil.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Where's my uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Gone after his lawyers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I wish I had seen him before he went out.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: He'll be in again presently, I dare say.—But I don't believe he knows any thing of this bustle; for Donna Marcella was retired to her chamber last night, before he returned from the governor's: and I am sure they have not seen one another this morn∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I should have been glad of an opportunity to talk to him, for all that; for I might have told him, first—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why there, to be sure, Sir, you wou'd have had an advantage: and after all, if there is to be an accusation trump'd up on either side, have not you as good a right to question Donna Marcella about the man, as she has to call you to an account about the woman?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And so I have, every bit.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: For as we say, Sir, what's law for the clerk, is law for the curate.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But, for my part, I look upon all this to be a fetch; a stroke of female artifice; in order to bring about some scheme or other, which I have hi∣therto been unable to discover.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nothing more likely, Sir; and, in that case, depend upon it, Madam Beatrice is the person who has put every thing into her head.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, she is a fiend incarnate! the very serpent, in woman's flesh! and if I was you, Sir, the first article I stipulated, before I married Donna Marcella, shou'd be, that she turn'd that Jezabel out of her service.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I will stipulate it; and insist upon it too.—But I can tell you, Lazarillo, I am now in very great doubt, whether I shall marry or not; for there is something in this letter, that tries my temper to such a degree—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No wonder, Sir; any gentleman's temper wou'd be tried by it:—and, to speak my opinion, if I was in your place, I wou'd no more tye myself—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: At least, I will behave with a proper spirit upon the occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay that I wou'd do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am determined on it.—I suppose she is in her chamber there—I'll go into her, and desire an explanation of her behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: That's right, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I will, indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: For my part, I believe I shou'd hardly be able to keep my hands off her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Stay, Lazarillo; I find myself in a violent agitation.—Do you knock at the door, and tell Beatrice, I wou'd be glad to speak with her lady, while I walk without to recover myself a little.

DIV2.STAGE: Lazarillo, who immediately knocks at Marcella's door; and afterwards Beatrice, who comes out of the room.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: My master's in a confounded passion, that I see, tho' he endeavours to stifle it.—He shan't marry, and ruin himself, if I can help it.—(Knocking at the door louder than before.)—Oh! what, you are asleep, are you?—I'll waken you, with a vengeance. (Knocks with his heel.)

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (Opening the door.) Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Good morning to you, sweet Mrs. Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Not much, my love. I have only a word or two from my master to your mistress; if you'll be so good as to carry them for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I think you have a great deal of impudence, to beat at my lady's door in that manner. Where do you imagine you are?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P:
I shan't know where I am presently, if you continue to look at me with that sour countenance.—But as to my impudence; I confess the charge: it has lot me two or three places already.—And when I consider the matter, I can't help wondering
how you have managed to stay in this family so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I shan't answer such a fellow as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You are too obliging:—it is doing just as I wou'd have you.—Don't say a word to me, I be∣seech you?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And what shou'd make me afraid of saying a word to you?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I thought you said this moment, you did not think me worth an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I'll say fifty words; a hundred, if I take it into my head.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: A thousand. Nobody doubts it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And, if I will, I'll be silent.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: If you can, you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Has any body given you a right to prevent my talking?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nobody at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I shou'd not have thought of such a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nor I, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It is not you, nor your father, nor your mother, nor all your dirty generation, shou'd make me hold my tongue, if I did not like it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Go on; go on: if you like to talk, why I like to hear you.—What! stop'd all of a sudden!—(Looking at him in silence.)—Not a word more to throw to a dog.—(Shaking her head, with a grimace of contempt.)—That turbulent member laid asleep that has so long kept the house in an uproar!—(Staring in his face.)—Why, thou most inveterate duenna.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Duenna!—What do you mean by that, you impertinent puppy? Do I look like a duenna? But I'll call those shall deal with you properly.—Ma'am, will you be so good as to step out here, and speak to Don Ferdinand's footman.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter, on different sides, Marcella, and Don Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What is this disturbance?—Oh, are you there, Lazarillo!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Yes Ma'am.—No Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No, Ma'am, I am here.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Don't be afraid; stand your ground, I'll second you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I'm not afraid, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: How can you, Donna Marcella, have the confidence to look me in the face, after writing me this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How can you look me in the face, Don Ferdinand, after giving me occasion to write that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I gave you no occasion. You charge me here with a thing which I am utterly ignorant of.—An offence in the clouds.—I don't know what you mean, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, indeed!—Do you hear him, Beatrice? He says, he does not know what I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh fye, Sir; how can you talk—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I don't, by Heaven's;—You accuse me here of bringing a woman into your father's house.—When?—how?—If ever I have seen a woman here, since I came into the house, but such as belong to it, I wish I may—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You had better endeavour to persuade me that I saw none either.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Ay, persuade my lady to that if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And pray, Mrs. Beatrice, what business have you to meddle in the dispute?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Because I have.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Lazarillo, be quiet. I beg, cousin, you will not urge me any farther upon this ridiculous affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: By no means; but you will give me leave to believe my senses, my eyes, and my ears.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ferdinand.
SP.P:
(Taking her kindly by the hand.) Well, but we are both too much inclined to be in a passion; let us reason the matter coolly together, and I will convince you, that, in this case, whatever you saw or heard, must have deceived
you; at least you are deceived in the inferences you have drawn from it: for, supposing their was a wo∣man here, only consider with yourself what proba∣bility, nay, what possibility is there, that I should have been accessary to her introduction?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No; I'll answer for it, my master knew no more of the matter—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (Suddenly letting her go) In short, ma'am, I must tell you, the thing is so palpably against rea∣son and common sense, that your affecting to believe it, looks as if you had some secret motive, at least as dishonourable to you, as the reality of the offence would have been to me, had I committed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You said we were to be cool, Don Fer∣dinand; keep your temper.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am cool, ma'am; but when one is provoked by an outrage of this nature—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Falling into a fury is by no means a proof of innocence; and, since you think proper to ap∣peal to appearances for your justification, I must tell you, they all make strongly against you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Demonstrate that, ma'am, and I shall have nothing more to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I'll be judged by Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Observe that—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh yes, Sir, they all make against you, indeed; I am sure I would be very unwilling to be∣lieve such a thing, if there was not all the reasons in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And what reasons, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: More than one or two either; but, pray, let me ask you, Sir, why did you engage Don Guz∣man to hire these lodgings, unknown to my mistress, and all of a sudden too, when we had better where we were; but that you might have an opportunity of introducing a mistress into them?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (laughing) Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Laughing is no confutation, Don Ferdi∣nand.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Then, Sir, going out as you have done, these two or three nights, at unseasonable hours? I'm sure it could never be for any thing good. But most of all, what a work was there last night, about hav∣ing your bed-chamber next to the outward room; which, I am satisfied, could be for no earthly pur∣pose, but to bring in and let out your women with more conveniency.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And these, madam, are the evidences on which you ground your indictment?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Answer them, if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I cou'd; but it is beneath me. I shall only tell you, ma'am, that there is nothing in them; and I expect you will believe it; but, before mat∣ters of a more serious nature go any farther between us, I shall demand some other instances of compli∣ance on your side: and the first point I insist upon is, that you turn off your chambermaid there, Mrs. Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Turn me off! Oh, lord, ma'am, have I—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: That my master insists upon—stick to it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I say, ma'am, in the first place, I insist upon her being turned off; absolutely never to be employed about you again. And, in the next place, ma'am, I desire to know who the man was I found in the house last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The man, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Ay, ma'am; the man in the mask? I'm sure you saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Beatrice!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, ma'am, when the swords were drawn, I don't know but I did see a man; but, I believe, it was one of the woman's—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Unjust Marcella!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
Come, come, Don Ferdinand, this artifice will not succeed; my education has been too strict, and my conduct too exemplary, to admit of a doubt prejudicial to my reputation. I know not who you have seen, nor do I care; but this I tell you peremp∣torily,
and call Heaven to attest it, that I never will be your wife, till I know who the woman was that Beatrice and I saw, in your chamber, last night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: You are resolved upon it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Finally; irrevocably.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Very well.—Now hear my resolve. By Heaven, I never will be your husband, till I know who the man was I met, last night, in the anti∣chamber. And so, madam, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Your servant. Now cry your eyes out.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice, and then Don Guzman, with a Lawyer and Notary: servants, afterwards, bring in chairs and tables.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Turn me off, indeed; I assure him I should not chuse to venture myself in the house with him, now I know what sort of a gentleman he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh, my dear Beatrice, I am hardly able to support myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, ma'am! I'm sorry for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: His effrontery has quite shocked me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am! here's your father, and his lawyers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Don't say a word of what has happened, Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, ma'am, to be sure I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Come, gentlemen, give me leave to bring you into this chamber: I have ordered things to be got ready for our business.—Where are these fellows? Why don't they bring in tables and chairs? Daughter, good morning to you. Heydey! What's the matter with you, child? You are not well; let me feel your pulse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am pretty well, Sir; but I have had but an indifferent night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P:
An indifferent night! By my faith one would think you had not slept this fortnight; but I see what it is; you are a silly girl, and have been blubbering: has not she been blubbering? I re∣member
her mother did nothing else for a week, before she was married to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: If you'll let my lady alone, Sir, she'll come to herself presently.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Where is my nephew, now! Where is Don Ferdinand? I sent for him as soon as I came in; but, I suppose, I must go call him myself after all.

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: No, Don Guzman; I believe the young gentleman is here.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Ferdinand, and Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Do you want me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Do I want you? Why, to be sure, Sir, I do want you; where the mischief is it you hide your∣self? You should have been here the first, and now you come the last.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Sir, I came as soon—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: You have no gallantry; when I was a young man—Come let us take our places. You, gentlemen, at that table, with your parchments; and you children, seat yourselves here on each side of me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (sitting down) Ugh!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: So, so! what ails you? Have you got the melancholies too? Catch'd the dumps of your cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Dumps, Sir! I don't know what you mean; I never was merrier in my life; I'll laugh till my sides are sore, if you desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Laugh till your sides are sore, you silly boy! There's no occasion for that either. Come, gentlemen, have you got every thing ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: Yes, Don Guzman, every thing is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Daughter, why don't you sit down here when I desire it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, I chuse—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, pray sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (sitting down) Why it will be the same thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I never saw two creatures look as you do in my life: what in the name of folly is the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I have told you already, Sir, that I am not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Not.
SP.P: These you say, Don Guzman, are the parties?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Ay; you'll take notice, I give ten thou∣sand pistoles to my daughter, for the present; and the rest of my fortune at my death; only reserving a thousand crowns, to defray the expence of pro∣secuting Don Carlos de Pimentel, who kill'd her brother in a duel.

SP.SPEAKER: Not.
SP.P: Ten thousand pistoles; the residue of your fortune at your death; a thousand crowns to pro∣secute Don Carlos de Pimentel. 'Tis so set down, Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (rising) Let me see—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Shall we suffer them to go on with this farce, ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Don't talk to me, Sir; I desire to have no manner of conversation with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: O, very well, ma'am; I am as willing to avoid any thing of that kind as you can be.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (returning to his chair) What, what, what are you saying to one another?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I was not speaking at all, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D Guz.
SP.P: (sitting down) Well, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: Now, Don Guzman, we are come to your daughter's dowry, in case of widowhood.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: That depends upon my nephew; but, I suppose, he will not think five thousand crowns a year extravagant, with forty thousand as a provi∣sion for younger children.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Horrid idea!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Were not you speaking either?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, Sir, I did not say a word.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I'm sure you did though.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (behind Marcella's chair) No, Sir, my lady did not speak, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I'm not speaking to you, take notice.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (behind Don Ferdinand's chair) Put in your word agan.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Have you any objection to this settle∣ment, Don Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: By no means, Sir; make it double, if you think proper; or treble, or quadruple,

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Double, or treble, or quadruple! You are very indifferent, methinks. Come, gentlemen, set down what I have told you, and then we'll get the young folks to put their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (across D. Guzman) I shan't sign Don Fer∣dinand.

SP.SPEAKER: D Fer.
SP.P: Nor I, ma'am, assure yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: You are not speaking now, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (to Marcella) For Heaven's sake, dear ma'am—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (putting his hand before her mouth) Will you hold your—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (starting up) What are you two doig there?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nothing, Sir; it's Lazarillo won't let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I'm doing nothing to her, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: The devil's in you all, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Not.
SP.P: This is finished, Don Guzman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Finished is it? Well, before we go any farther, let us fix the day for the marriage; I have thought of Saturday; however, please yourselves; what say you, nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (rising) Why, Sir, if I must give my opinion▪ I think we had better defer it a little▪

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Defer it! How long?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: For ever, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (rising) And that's my opinion too, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Is it so indeed! And why is it your opinion pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (going out) Don Ferdinand will tell you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Come back, child, Marcella; (turning to Don Ferdinand) Don Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Enquire of your daughter, Sir, she can best inform you▪

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, Beatrice, Lawyer, Notary.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Gone! she one way, and he t'other, and I am left in the clouds; pray, Ma'am, can you solve this riddle? What's the matter with 'em; what has happen'd between your mistress, and her cousin, to occasion this sudden—I know not what to call it—Satan has possess'd them both I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Don't ask me any thing about it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Not ask you!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, Sir, I had rather you wou'd not.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What are you whimpering for?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I don't know, Sir, I can't help it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I desire you will tell me whatever has come to your knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, Sir, all I know about it, is this, Don Ferdinand brought a creature into the house here—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: A creature! When?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Last night, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, don't cry—And what creature was it? A lion, a tyger, a bear, a rhenoceros, a crocodile?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, Sir, I'm asham'd to tell you what it was.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Asham'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Besides, I don't know how you name them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No! It must be some strange monster sure, or you are grown devlish mealy mouth'd of a sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Courtezans I think they are call'd; your creatures, that run after the men.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Oh, ho! In short, Don Ferdinand brought a strumpet into my house last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I believe that's one of the names gentlemen give them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: And how do you know he did this?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Because I saw her, Sir—I catch'd her in his bed▪chamber, and my lady saw her too.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Very well, that's all I want with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (making a low courtsey as she goes out) Sir, your humble servant.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, Lawyer, Notary, Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: As the parties refuse to sign, Don Guzman, it will be needless for us to stay any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Hold, gentlemen; a moment's patience, I beg—(to Lazarillo) How now, Sir! what's your business here?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I want my master's hat, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Your master's hat! Come hither—I suppose you know the cause of this difference be∣tween my nephew and my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, my master has trusted me with every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Has he! Well, let me know all the par∣ticulars then; you need be under no apprehension, for I shall repeat nothing to your prejudice; and there's something to recompence your confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Sir, I am very much oblig'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: So, now tell me what you know.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why, Sir, (a little this way, because there is no occasion for those gentleman to hear us) last night, Sir, my master found a man, in one of the chambers within—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Your master found a man!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—I did not see him myself, you'll observe, but I've no doubt of the fact, tho' Donna Marcella denies it—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Hark, you rascal, do you see this cane in my hand?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Well, Sir, and what then, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why then, sirrah, how dare you have the impudence to trifle with me, knowing I have an instrument of chastiement so near? Tell me the truth, you dog; the whole truth this moment, or I'll break every bone in your skin.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I have told you the whole truth, Sir. Don Ferdinand, my master, your nephew, found a man in the house last night, that your daughter had hid there—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (striking him) Take that, and that, and that!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (going off) For shame, Sir, what's come over you; are you bewitch'd? Was ever such a cursed old fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Gentlemen, you see there is something wrong in my family; I really don't know what it is at present; but as it must be settled before we con∣clude matters, I will endeavour to get at the bottom of it, and let you know this evening, when we would trouble you again. I am so confounded, so vext, and in such a passion, that I protest I think I was never so in all my days: but I'll make them tell me this story, in a plain, intelligible manner; and my nephew shall satisfy me in every point, or I can tell him he shall never be nearer related to me, and he may go farther and not fare so well.

DIV2.STAGE: As soon as the stage is left void, Don Carlos opens a door in the back scene, and after peeping to see that the coast is clear, enters with Aurora leaning on his arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Only get me a little into the air, and I shall be well again presently.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: How do you find yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Better already.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Good God, what shall we do; and how unfortunate was it, that you came here, since our perverse stars decreed that the master key shou'd be of no use to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Who cou'd devine that centinels wou'd be plac'd to guard the door? However, let us not complain, but rather thank Providence, that we discover'd their being posted, which must other∣wise have ended in my shame, and your inevitable destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (drawing her a chair) Sit down here a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (leaning back) Heigho!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Aurora! she faints again—the heat of that cursed place, has overcome her so, that I shall never be able to fetch her to herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: 'Tis nothing but the sudden effects of the air. I assure you I am greatly recover'd, and shall be able to go in again immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I know the risk I run, in exposing my∣self to discovery—her retreat with me being known, will also subject her to a thousand dishonourable sus∣picions, tho' groundless; but her situation requires immediate assistance. If I can see Beatrice, I think I may venture to tell her my story, and commit Aurora to her care; she was formerly much in my interest; 'tis the only thing I have for it; and the worst come to the worst, my mask and my sword shall defend me from every body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Aurora
SP.P: What woman can say she will make but one false step? Alas, we tread upon ice, and in making one, thro' want of caution, we make a thousand. Nay, after that, accident takes the part of indiscre∣tion, and we even fall, in endeavouring to recover ourselves—Carlos! where is he? Don Carlos! how has he left me without my perceiving him; sure he is gone to tell Marcella, or her maid, my situation; I wou'd sooner die than they shou'd know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (within) Beatrice, Beatrice, where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Here, Ma'am, I'm a coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Heavens and earth, what do I hear! is not that Marcella's voice? Shou'd she find me in this place, shou'd she know where I have been, what wou'd she think of me—I am entangled so on every side, that it is imposible for me to extricate myself: must then the retreat I contriv'd for another, be my own destruction!

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella, Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Where's my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I don't know, Ma'am, but I've told him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Told him! what have you told him?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why, about the woman, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I'm sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Are you? I'm sorry too then; but you wou'd not have had me told him a lie, and he ask'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: In short, Beatrice, Don Ferdinand's be∣haviour has shaken my resolution—It betrays no marks of guilt; and, after all, if we shou'd be mis∣taken.—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nay, Ma'am, if there is any mistake, you led me into it I'm sure; for I said at first, the woman was only a thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am really afraid I have been too rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And now you are vex'd with yourself, I suppose; that's always the way when one's passion's over.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Go and desire my father to come to me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am; but pray now take care what you say to him, and don't let him lay all the blame upon me.

DIV2.STAGE: Marcella sits down in the chair, which Aurora had iust left, with her veil carelessly thrown over her face. Don Carlos enters behind.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P:
I have ventur'd as far as my appre∣hensions wou'd give me leave, but without being
able to meet Beatrice; however, it is so far well, that I have met nobody else—Perhaps her weak∣ness may now have left her (approaching Marcella, whose back he nly sees, and taking hold of her hand for Aurora's.) Dearest, tenderest creature, how is it with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (starting up with a scream) Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Confusion, what's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Who are you—Help!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: My head turns round, I shall drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Don Carlos de Pimentel!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: That wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Whence come you, Sir? How got you here?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What shall I say to her! (hesitating) Ma'am, I confess at the sight of you my blood freezes, my heart recoils, and I am neither in a state to hear or answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Your rasness, Sir, forces me to give you up to justice—Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Hold, Ma'am—Give me up to justice; having lost you, my life is not worth preserving; but where is the lady I left here just now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The lady, Sir, just now; lord, what lady, and what are you talking of? I saw no lady—The case is evident, his misfortunes have turn'd his brain.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: (aside) Aurora then, has recover'd, and gone back to our retreat; Marcella has not seen her, I had better say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Tell me, Sir, to what purpose are you come into this house? Is it the effect of madness, or design'd as an audacious insult upon our family?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What can I ay—only that I am the most unfortunate of men; that all imaginable distresses, accumulate upon my head; that these walls inclose the object I have so long ador'd, and so fatally lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
Proceed no farther, Sir—On reflection, I find myself in the most critical situation—My honour is at stake as well as your life—Only let me know in
one word, did you come here on purpose to meet destruction, or do you wish to avoid it?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Are you married to Don Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am not; nor do I believe I ever shall; but, good gentleman, endeavour to calm your tran∣ports; you frighten me, and may ruin us both.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: 'Tis true;—forgive the ravings of a distracted man;—I am distracted, I am distracted, Marcella;—where to go—how to act—what to ay—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Your father, and Don Ferdinand, are both gone—(Seeing Don Carlos.)—Ah, Ma'am! here is a man then, after all—and you wou'd not venture to trust me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The man is Don Carlos—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: De Pimentel!—We shall be every one hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How he got in, or his reason for coming, I cannot prevail on him to discover.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: How long has he been here, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I never saw him, till this moment, that he surprized me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Upon your word!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: For my part, I believe he is mad; for he talks in the strangest, wild, incoherent manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: His eyes look very ugly, I assure you;—stand farther from him, Ma'am, he may have broken from his keepers.—(Keeping at a distance, with her mistress by the arm.)—What do you want here, Sir? and which of our people let you in?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: None of your people let me in.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I suppose, then, you were the man Don Ferdinand saw last night?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And have you been here ever since?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I have,

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And where did you hide yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Where I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Have you been seen by any one in the house, besides my lady and me?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: We must get him out, Ma'am, while your father and Don Ferdinand are abroad; it will be better than calling the servants to take him, for reasons—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: But how shall we get him out?—He is sub∣ject to be seen by all the servants in the house, every one of whom know him;—and, at last, perhaps, he may be stopp'd by the centinels at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: The centinels!—I never thought of them.—Lord! Lord! how shall we contrive!—One can't think of hanging the wretch.—Stay, there's a thought come into my head.—If we can get the family out of the way, there is, in my room, a military hat and cloak of your late brother's; let him put on them; the centinels will take him for an officer—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My brother's cloak and hat!—I cannot think of it, Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Then, Ma'am, you must give him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I can't think of that either.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Sacrifice me; give me up; I am prepar'd for death, and desire to meet it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Ay, but we have too much regard for our∣selves, we thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: At any rate, Beatrice, carry him up into your chamber for the present.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I will, Ma'am.—Come, Sir.—There's something that puzzles me in this business notwithstanding; for, I can hardly believe the man wou'd come into this house, merely for the sake of being hang'd, let my lady say what she pleases.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A street; with a view, near the bottom of the stage, of Don Guzman's house, with two centinels at the door.
Don Ferdinand enters with Don Pedro.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: THE Duke of Medina, then, is entirely out of danger?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: His physicians pronounced him so this morning. I told you, that the colonel of the regi∣ment, to which I belong, was now at Madrid; I knew him to be a man of honour, and was sure of his friendship. I writ him a candid account of my rencounter with the Duke, to whom he immediately went; and he managed matters so well, that just now he came to the place of my retreat with the message I have repeated to you: that his Grace took the blame of the whole affair upon himself, and assured me, upon his honour, he would not suffer me in any way to be troubled or molested about it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: It speaks the generosity which always ought to distinguish the nobleman. You may be∣lieve, being in a great measure the instrument of your misfortune, I more than participated in the un∣easiness it gave you. But I hope the remainder of your stay at Madrid will not be less agreeable, for the unlucky accident which threatened to cloud it, so soon after your arrival.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P:
