Was my peace, and honour, entirely in my own keeping, I flatter myself neither one, nor the other, would be often in danger: but what shall I say to you, Don Ferdinand?—Last night, my sister, whom I had placed in a neigh∣bouring convent, taking advantage of the indis∣position of the abbess, and the retirement of the
rest of the community, imposed upon a silly old nun, injudiciously trusted with the keys of the house; she let her go out, as she says, but for an hour; and from that time, to this, she has never been heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Let her out! Upon what pretence?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I cannot clearly learn. Her maid, who is left behind, says her mistress did not intrust her with the secret: the nun has been interrogated again, and again; but she is so old, her memory is so feeble, and she gives such a confused account, that it is impossible to form any conjectures upon what she says.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But can you form no conjectures your∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Why, it is a suspicion I am unwilling to divulge; but to tell you the truth, from your hav∣ing seen Don Carlos de Pimentel the other evening, I have no manner of doubt, that she is either hid with him some where in Madrid, or that she is fled with him from hence.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: This is extraordinary, very extraordinary, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I think, Don Ferdinand, you yourself seem to be in a state of mind, to-day, far from perfectly tranquil; what is the matter with you? I hope my vexations are not contagious.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No; but to be sincere with you, a little disturbance has happened this morning at home, which puts me somewhat out of sorts: I am angry with others, and angry with myself; but as there are faults on both sides, I hope all will be put again in the right channel.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I hope so too; for, believe me, nothing could augment my own sufferings more, than a knowledge of your having any thing to make you materially uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Hold, Don Pedro, stand back a litte; do you see the fellow that creeps yonder under the wall, looking behind him every moment?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Ay, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: He comes this way. I have my reasons for it; let us stand a little under that piazza, and observe him.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Muskato.
DIV2.P: What an infernal thing is a life of apprehension! I wish I may never stir, if my fear has not almost melted me into a jelly: (clapping his hands behind him, between his waistcoat and coat.) Ay, ay; thro' shirt, waistcoat, and all; I could not be in a finer perspiration, if the whole college of physicians had been endeavouring to bring me to it. Well, how it will end, Heaven knows; I am out of the house, that's one comfort; and in some measure the way is paved for my master; for I have been among his friends, and six of them, brave, sturdy, young fellows, armed with swords and pistols, will be ready to favour his escape; the hour they are determined on is the most convenient that can be, when our Dons are taking their digestive naps after dinner. I only wait their arrival, to give Don Carlos the signal from this little popper; (shews a pocket pistol) but I must first take a view of the house, which I may do with safety, from yonder corner, in order to determine on which side I had best stand, when I give the alarm, that it may be sure to come to my master's ears. (going off, with his face towards the audience, suddenly starts, and turns.) Who do you want? It is not I! Lord have mercy upon me, I thought some one had touched my shoulder. I'll shoot the first man that assaults me.
DIV2.STAGE: Don Ferdinand, Don Pedro, and then Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: 'Tis he, I'm positive.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I think so too.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Hold a little. (ringing at Don Guzman's door, Lazarillo comes out.) Come this way, you Sir; do you see the man that goes along yonder, with his hat flapped over his face? Pass by him, and try if you know who he is. (Lazarillo goes out.) The fellow's not at home, whom I sent to dog Don Carlos, the night before last, or he could tell di∣rectly whether this is the same person that was with him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Your man has taken a thorough survey of his whole person.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (to Lazarillo returning.) Well, Sir, do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I think I have seen his face before.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Is he the servant of Don Carlos de Pi∣mentel?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: The very man.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Then let us go, and seize him directly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Hold, Don Ferdinand, you and your servant will be sufficient to deal with him, and it is absolutely necessary for me, to pay the compli∣ment of calling at the duke of Medina's imme∣diately; however, I'll be with you at your house in less than half an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Do so. Lazarillo, follow me.

DIV2.STAGE: Scene changes to a room in Don Guzman's house, Bea∣trice enters; and afterwards on the opposite side enter Marcella.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (looking about her.) Come, Ma'am, he may venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (within.) Is the coast quite clear, Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, I have sent all the other men out of the way, and Lazarillo is just this moment gone down the street. But let him make haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (within.) I'll fetch him.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: The dickens take him, he has put me in such a tremble, as I have not been in this twelve∣month; and frights ruin one's complexion too: I dare swear I shall look pale for a week. Well, Ma'am, what are you staying for?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (entering.) Bless my soul, Beatrice, I can't find Don Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Not find him, Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No; I left him in the room a few minutes ago; and when I came back, he was not there.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Mercy, mercy; let me go look for him.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Carlos, with the hat, cloak, and regimen∣tals of a Spanish officer.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I beg your pardon—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, where do you run? My mistress, and I, have been terrified out of our senses.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I thought to follow your mistress, but by mistake turned into a wrong chamber, and could not find my way. (turning to Marcella.) Will you permit me to say a few words to Mrs. Beatrice, in private?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: In private to me! Mercy on us, what!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Don't be alarmed, it is only a little com∣mission I have to charge you with. (taking her aside.) In the first place, my dear girl, there is my purse, and ten thousand thanks for the kind interest you have taken in my misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh, dear Sir, your servant, I am always ready and willing to assist any one in distress; and I wish you may get safe out of Madrid, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Well, but this is not all I have to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P:
No. There is another person still in this house, for whom I must intreat your good of∣fices; and should there be occasion and opportu∣nity,
I beg you will convey that person out, unseen by your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, but I don't understand you; explain this matter to me a little more.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I can't explain it farther, at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Another person still in the house, that I must endeavour—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Beatrice, we are losing time.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Very true, Ma'am—that I must endeavour to get out, unknown to my lady. Who is it?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: What signifies? you'll see.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, but you've set me quite on the fidgets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Upon my word, Beatrice, we shall delay so long—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: We are ready, Ma'am. Come, Sir, let me look at you; the cloaths fit him mighty well; I dare swear the centinels will take him for an officer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I hope so.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You must be cautious not to shew any con∣fusion. Come along the hall with a strut, and in passing by, look impudent, more impudent still; you'll not look half impudent enough.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Never fear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: But you leave my curiosity horribly on the stretch, Sir. I wish you would tell me what you meant, by the thing you said to me just now.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Once more, Ma'am, and for the last time, I'm afraid, I take my leave of you; but, if any accident untinged with my misfortunes, should again bring us together, let me flatter myself—

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, is the person a man, or a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Beatrice, farewell—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Have a moment's patience; I am a little uneasy; I think I see a crowd of people coming to∣wards our door, and, if I am not mistaken, Don Ferdinand is among them.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Stay, Ma'am, let me look. Oh, mon∣strous!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I don't know.—Don Ferdinand, and La∣zarillo, and two or three more, have laid hold of a man, and are dragging him along; and I wish I may die, Don Carlos, if the person they have got, is not very like your servant Muskato.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Then the work of my destruction is com∣plete.—Come, Ma'am, have the merit of giving me up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I give you up, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: They are bringing him into the house.—Quick, quick, let us get back to my chamber, as fast as we can.

DIV2.STAGE: Scene changes to another chamber in Don Guzman's house, in which is the moveable pannel. Don Fer∣dinand enters, attended by Lazarillo, and other ser∣vants, with Muskato, whom they have got by the collar.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Pull the rascal in here; pull him in; and if he attempts to struggle, knock him down.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Well, but gentlemen, good, dear gen∣tlemen, as you are men of honour, and Catholic Christians, don't do me any hurt.—I am a poor mi∣serable young fellow, but just turn'd of four and twenty, that have an old mother, and two lame sisters—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Aren't you a villain, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: You are pleas'd to say so, Sir; and I shan't be so unmannerly as to contradict any gentleman, with a sword at my throat.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Aren't you the servant of that assassin, Don Carlos de Pimentel?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Upon my word Sir, I can't say;—perhaps I may, and perhaps I mayn't;—you have frighten'd every thing quite out of my head;—I have no more memory than a dry'd whiting.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: He is his servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Well, Sir; yes, I am his servant, if that will content you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Where's your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (Laughing.) Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Do you make a jest of us?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: No, Sir, no; but I am ticklish, and your man has got his fingers in my collar: bid him take them away, and I'll speak.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Let him go.—Well, now, Sir, where is Don Carlos?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: He's in a place.—(Looking towards the pannel.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: In a place! what place?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Stay, let me recollect myself a little. I never was so flurry'd since I was born. Indeed, gen∣tlemen, you have not done well to scare me in this manner: it may throw me into a fever; or some other ugly disorder; and, I am sure, you have so much good nature, that you wou'd be sorry for it afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: You will trifle with us, then. Answer my question, directly, or torture shall make you.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Propose it again, good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Where is Don Carlos de Pimentel?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Not a great way off. (Looking again at the pannel.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: So we suppose, by your being here.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: He is, at present, I believe—Pray, Sir, will you do me the favour to tell me what o'clock it is?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What a clock!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; because I wou'd be as precise in answering your question, as possible: and, if it is now about half an hour after one, as I partly con∣jecture, Don Carlos is at this moment, picking his teeth, after dinner, in the city of Lisbon.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: 'Tis false, sirrah; I know he is at this moment hid somewhere in Madrid.—Lay hold of him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P:
Don't touch me for your lives.—I desire to know, gentlemen, since you come to this, how
long it has been the custom in Spain, to lay violent hands on people, without officers, and without war∣rants?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: We'll tell you that by and by.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Marcella and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: There is really nothing in this house, from morning till night, but noise and confusion.—What is the matter here?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Only a couple of alguazils, Madam, as you may perceive by their dress, that have got a poor criminal in their clutches, and are going to play the devil with him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: This is the servant of Don Carlos de Pi∣mentel; I catched him just now in the street, mea∣suring the outside of our house, with his eyes, from top to bottom.—I know his master is at present in Madrid; and I suspect, this emissary of his was not lurking about this neighbourhood for any good pur∣pose:—rather, perhaps, in meditation of some far∣ther destruction of our family;—for, searching his pockets, we found a pistol.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: You found a pistol!—Do you say you found a pistol in my pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: There it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Oh, do you call that a pistol?—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Ay; what do you call it?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: I keep it to light my pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well but, Sir, let me look at this person; because I was very well acquainted with Don Carlos, and his servant too, if this be the same he had before he left Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Do look at me, Ma'am; did you ever see my face before?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Never, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: See there, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why you yourself said but now, that you belong'd to Don Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Did I?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Yes, this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: I don't think I said any such thing: and I am almost sure I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, you are mistaken here;—he that liv'd with Don Carlos, us'd to make love to me;—a good, genteel, personable fellow:—whereas, this is one of the worst looking, ill-made, aukward, ugly hounds, I ever saw in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Sir, believe what I say to you; this is the servant that liv'd with Don Carlos, when he was last in Madrid; and he was always just as ugly as he is now. I even recollect his name; it began with juss—or fuss—or—

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: There is neither juss nor fuss in my name; so you may give me my liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No, Sir, I arrest you—

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: You can't; let me see your warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I think you had better turn him about his business.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I think the contrary.—Pray, Ma'am, you and your maid return to your chamber.—Lazarillo, lock that door, and give me the key—(To Mu∣skato, who endeavours to steal away.)—'Tis in vain to strive to escape, Sir; I shall leave you lock'd up here, till I come back with proper officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (Pulling Lazarillo by the sleeve.) Young man, I find myself a little indispos'd; if you have any such thing as a drop of spirits in the house, I would be oblig'd to you for—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Oh! you'll be in greater want of spirits pre∣sently;—you had better keep them for a more pressing occasion.

DIV2.STAGE: Muskato, Aurora.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: (Knocking at the wainscot.) Open;—open;—'tis▪ I.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (Coming out veil'd.) Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P:
Hey-day, what have you done to yourself! have you got into petticoats too?—Gad, I don't
know but you are much in the right of it; for there is an old gentleman hereabouts, who conducts ladies out of his house, with an admirable politeness.—But, joking apart, I suppose you have heard what has happen'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I endeavoured to listen; but the noise was so great, I could hear nothing distinctly.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: You cou'd hear nothing distinctly!—(Squeaking to mimic her.)—What the devil, have you put your voice into petticoats too?—I left you a double bass; and, I find you a treble.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (Shewing her face) Come, a truce with these impertinencies.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Donna Aurora!—For Heaven's sake, worthy young gentlewoman, how came you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: 'Tis a long story to tell:—however, make yourself easy; your master has escaped.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: My master!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Donna Marcella, the daughter of Don Guz∣man, in whose way he happened to fall, undertook to set him at liberty. He came here, just now, and offered to stay with me, or make me the companion of his escape: the former, you may be sure, I would not hear of; and, in the latter case, I thought I should only be an impediment to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Well, but stay—Donna Marcella, and he—and you—and coming and going—This is all hicktius doxius to me.—When did you see Donna Marcella?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: She does not know I am here;—my great mortification is, that I am afraid I shall at last be obliged to discover myself to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (Through the key-hole.) Muskato! Muskato!

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: 'Tis I—Beatrice—have they lock'd you up?

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Ay, double lock'd me up—I am lock'd up on both sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd let you out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I wish you could, into the street—How did you get out my master?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: We have him here within; and he says he won't go without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I am very much obliged to him; but what good will that do me? However, at any rate, I should be glad to take my leave of him, before we part. I wish you would strive to put back the lock of the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It's impossible; but comfort yourself; my lady, and I, have been both crying for you; and I dare swear we shall cry a great deal more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: You think we shall suffer then.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Take care of yourself; Don Ferdinand is coming up the other way, with the alguazils.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (Running to the pannel) Is he? By Gad, then I will take all the care I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Stay, Muskato (her foot slipping as she goes to follow him.) Oh, gracious Heaven! I have hurt my∣self, and they are opening the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: (dropping the pannel) Nay, if you won't come: charity begins at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (on the outside) Muskato!

DIV2.STAGE: Aurora, Don Ferdinand, Don Pedro, Lazarillo, and Alguazils.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (without) Yes, yes, my friend Lazarillo and I seized him; and we have him here, under lock and key.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: On no account quit him till he discovers where Don Carlos is; tho' I believe the law will in∣volve him in his master's crime.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Shame and destruction, my brother's voice!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (entering) Stand by there, and let the of∣ficers pass; here, gentlemen, is the Corigidor's war∣rant, and there's your prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: We are ready to do yonr duty, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Hey, what have we got—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: A woman in a veil!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Where's the servant of Don Carlos?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Is not he there, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And what woman's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: If you can't produce the criminal, Don Fer∣dinand, it is impossible for us to take him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Hold, gentlemen (searching the chamber.) By Heavens, I left him locked up here, and have had the key in my pocket ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Why don't you see who the woman is?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: (approaching Aurora) I'll see that.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (Aurora making a motion with her hand) Stand off.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: She beckens to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I desire, gentlemen, you won't leave the house yet.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: To speak to me in private, ma'am? Is there any thing particular that you can't say before these people?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Very well, ma'am, it shall be so. La∣zarillo, take the officers with you into the next room: and, let me beg of you, Don Pedro, to stand at the door, to have an eye that they don't go away.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I must discover myself to him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, now, ma'am; who, and what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Answer these questions yourself, Sir (lifting up her veil;) for the rest, my sex, and my mis∣fortunes, give me claim to your protection.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Aurora, the sister of Don Pedro! Where is the man I left here; and by what unaccountable accident—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: A time will come for satisfying you in every thing: consider, at present, but the peril of my situation; my brother is here; I am a woman; and you are a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am really under such astonishment! However, I pledge my word for your safety, while you are here; let down your veil; and, if pos∣sible, I will get rid of Don Pedro, till I convey you into some other place.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: How now! Your countenance seems changed of a sudden: who is this veiled woman?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: An unfortunate person of my acquaint∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: She seems to have thrown you into great perplexity.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Into greater than it is possible to imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Can I be of any service to you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I'll speak to her, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: It must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I'll be hanged but she is some mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No, upon my word; but—

DIV2.STAGE: Don Ferdinand, Don Pedro, Aurora, and Don Guzman, behind the scenes.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz▪
SP.P: Alguazils in my house again! This is really monstrous: how come the centinels to let these people up? If you seek Don Pedro Pacheco, gentlemen, I tell you once for all—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Was ever man so embarrassed as I am! Here's my uncle now; if he finds a woman with me, and I refuse to give an account how she came, he will believe the story Marcella told him concern∣ing last night; if I discover her, I shall involve my∣self in a quarrel with her brother, besides breaking my word given to her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: You are greatly concerned about some∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am; I confess it.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Don Ferdinand, do you hesitate to preserve me?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P:
No, Ma'am, I will endeavour to preserve you, at any rate. My dear Don Pedro, don't be
surprized at what I am going to say to you: it stands me upon to keep this lady from my uncle's sight; I beg, therefore, you will not mention any thing about her: and pray, ma'am, do you step into this cabinet.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Shall I shut myself up with her?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No; stay where you are.

DIV2.STAGE: Don Ferdinand, Don Pedro, and Don Guzman, speaking to Lazarillo, who goes across; afterwards enter on the opposite side, Marcella and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Go you, Sir, and desire my daughter to come to me immediately. Nephew, I am very angry with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am sorry for that, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: A fig for your sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Don Guzman, I kiss your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I am glad to see you out of your trouble, Don Pedro; you know what I am going to say: I was well acquainted with your father, he was an honest, obliging, kind hearted man, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Here I am, Sir, what's your pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What, you won't let me enjoy ease and quietness? (To D. Pedro) I have been worried these two days in such a manner, you would really pity me, if you knew it; and now I find my house full of bailiffs. They tell me, nephew, you have seized the servant of Don Carlos de Pimentel.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, but he has escaped.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: How has he escaped?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: That's more than I am able to say. I left him locked up here; and, when I came back again, I could not find him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Oh, very well; I warrant you I'll find him: I hear tales of a very ugly nature from one side and the other, of men and women being con∣cealed in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P:
'Tis most certain, Sir, that I met a strange
man in the house last night; but I don't pretend to determine how he got in.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: My daughter says there was a strange woman; and, for any thing that appears to the con∣trary, both the lurking toads may be in the house still; and, if somebody does not ferrit them out, we may have our throats cut one of these nights, when we are asleep in our beds, and dreaming of no such matter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, I can't think they are in the house still.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Oh, but I'll be sure; and, therefore, I am determined to hunt every hole and corner. And first, I'll begin to examine this room (going to∣wards the closet where Aurora is.) Perhaps they may have hid themselves—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: (placing himself before the closet) Hold, Sir, you must not go in here.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No! And why not pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Do go in, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Nephew, I will go into that place.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, I have the greatest re∣spect for you, but here my honour is engag'd; and by Heaven, I will defend this door with my life.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: This is very pretty behaviour, I protest; however, Sir, since you are so violent, I will not contend with you at present; I'll take this room in my way back: and will you, Don Pedro, be so obliging as to accompany me, while I search the rest of the apartments.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: (very quick) He'll go into my chamber, Ma'am, and find Don Carlos.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Hold, pray, Sir, stay a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What mischief's in the wind now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You must not go in this way, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Must not! by my faith but I will tho'

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: For shame, Sir, it looks as if you doubted my lady's honour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And why shou'd not your lady's honour be doubted as well as mine? I say, Sir, do go in.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: And so I—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, don't think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Then I'll go in there.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No, Sir, that must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why now did ever any one see the like of this? I say, nephew, daughter—

DIV2.STAGE: Aurora, throwing open the doors of the cabinet, comes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: Ruin I see must overtake me, and therefore I'll meet it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: So, so, so!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, was I right or wrong?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Right, Ma'am; there is a woman, and I shall have something to say to her presently.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Uncle, upon my honour, this is a lady of condition, who is here by mere accident—Don Pedro can tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Nephew, I cou'd not have believ'd such a thing of you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Well, but, Sir, let Don Ferdinand explain the matter, he is my friend; I know him, and I am satisfied he is incapable—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Come, Ma'am, shew your face, till we see with what justice you are preferr'd to others.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why don't you pull off your veil?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: There! Now are you satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: (Aurora discovering herself) Fury and death, my sister! Villain, draw your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Nay now, Don Pedro, you are out of your wits.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Hear me, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: I'll hear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I'll leave it to all the world now, if ever there was a poor old fellow so hamper'd, and plagu'd, by a set of young rascals, and husseys, as I am.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lazarillo.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Where's Don Guzman, where's my master. Oh gentlemen, gentlemen, gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: D Ped.
SP.P: Don Ferdinand, follow me out directly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: (stopping them) Pray hold a little—What ails this fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Lazarillo, have you seen a ghost?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You have hit it, the house is haunted.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Yes, with a pack of mad people.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Spirits, Sir, spirits—As I am a living man, your son, Don Alonzo appeared to me this instant, upon the stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Pshaw, you simpleton, you have seen a white sheet, or a cat run across you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No, Sir, I saw your son, in his regimental cloaths; I saw him as plain as I see you—His face was as long as my arm, and as pale as a piece of chalk; his eyes glared like two coals of fire, and he had a flambeau in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I won't believe a word of this, it's all a monstrous lie—A ghost, and a piece of chalk, and a flambeau, and stuff; draw all your swords and follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (sinks into Ferdinand's arms) Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: My lady faints, my lady faints!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: Fetch water here.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Why does she faint this way!

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Sir, I'll tell you; (falling on her knees.) I'll tell you, Sir, if you'll promise not to be angry; for I find it is in vain to keep the thing a secret from you any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Well, I'll not be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: My lady has done nothing she need be ashamed of, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No, so I am in hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nor are either she, or I, to blame; for the person that's here, got in, without our knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: What person?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, don't be angry!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: I tell you I won't be angry; I am only thunder-struck. Here, you, man, ghost, devil, or whatever you are, make your appearance; I protest before Heaven, I'll do you no harm, but forgive you all, and let you go quietly about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: The ghost! the ghost! the ghost!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: The fool, the blockhead, the ass. I could find in my heart to thrash you while I am able to stand over you.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Carlos, with his mask on, and his sword drawn. After advancing some paces towards the middle, he discovers himself.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Don Guzman, I take you at your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.P: Don Carlos de Pimentel!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Call in the alguazils.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: No, come back. How have you the audaciousness, Don Carlos▪ to appear in this place? And what do you think must be the consequence of my seeing you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I came not to Madrid to brave your en∣mity, Don Guzman, but to engage the assistance of my friends. I was invited by this lady, to this house, where, by a train of accidents, as extraor∣dinary as unavoidable, I have been shut up against my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: This is true. To be more particular, or to tell you how I became entangled in the same perplexities with him, is what neither our present situation, or the state of my spirits will allow.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Did not you kill my son?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P:
I should have been unworthy to live my∣self, had I supported an affront from any man; condemn not me, but custom, which makes such
resentments laudable. Your son was the agres∣sor; I came not upon him like a bravo, or an as∣sassin, but where the injury was received, in the face of day, staked my life upon the justness of my quar∣rel. The same chance, which led my sword to Don Alonzo's breast, might have directed his to mine: the fall of your son rendered me unhappy, but could not make me guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Uncle, on what do you ruminate?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: I have delivered myself into your hands, Don Guzman, on the faith of your promise, that the memory of all past acts should be cancelled be∣tween us; but conscious of my innocence, I disdain to owe my safety to an undesigned clemency; recall what you have said, I release you from your word, if you can have more pleasure in satisfying an unjust revenge, than in sacrificing it to a point of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Go away, and never let me see you more.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Ped.
SP.P: This may do for you, Don Guzman, but I am to be answered in another manner. The death of a son may be forgiven, but not the ruin of a ster.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Don Pedro, I never wrong'd you. I honour, I esteem, I admire your sister; and not out of fear of your anger, but in regard to her virtues, and as a debt due to her reputation, brought into danger, by her attention to me, I am willing to make her my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Where is the flambeaux you had just now? If you have left it behind you, it may burn the house.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Flambeaux, Sir, I had no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Did not you say he had a flambeaux?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Don't ask me any thing about it—I don't know what he had.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: (going apart with Don Pedro.) Brother—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P:
There is one circumstance, in this dark affair, which surprizes me more than any thing else. Where is your servant, Don Carlos, whom I seized
just now in the street? I left him locked up here, and in less than a quarter of an hour—

DIV2.STAGE: Don Guzman, Don Carlos, Don Ferdinand, Don Pedro, Aurora, Marcella, Beatrice, Lazarillo, and Muskato, who lifts up the pannel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Heigho!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Who have we bricked up in the wall, yoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Are we all friends; is it peace, and good fellowship, without respect of persons?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Muskato!

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: At your service, Ma'am; and gentlemen, and ladies, I humbly salute you all.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Sirrah, I desire to know—

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I am included in the treaty, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What place have we got here? This brings things into my head. Hark, you rogue's face, was not it you that stole my gown?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Si, Signora.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Well, and where is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Why, you must know I put it on.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Put on my gown!

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Oh Lord, yes; I make one of the genteelest ladies you ever laid your eyes on; ask Don Guz∣man else. Being somewhat more corpulent than you, indeed, your gown has suffered a little in the seams; but don't make yourself uneasy; to reom∣pence the damage, when our things come from Por∣tugal, I'll make you a present of one of the sweetest pretty creatures of a lap-dog, between a mastiff and an Italian greyhound, about this high from the ground—(holding his hand about a yard up.)

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Hang your filthy mongrel, he's fit for no∣thing but to watch a tan-yard. Make your master give me a new gown, for the one you have spoiled.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Here's my hand, it shall be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P:
(Coming forward with Don Pedro) This is the fact, as well as it can be related, in a few words; wait, if you please, to be farther satisfied; but re∣member,
I can have no motive for deceiving you; and the way is open for an honourable reconci∣liation▪ before scandal and falsehood—

SP.SPEAKER: D Ped.
SP.P: What you tell me is very odd; however that is not a sufficient reason for my doubting the truth of it. Don Carlos, we have no leisure now, to enter into discussions and explanations; your fa∣mily and fortune are unexceptionable; you say you are willing to marry my sister; take her, and may you be happy together.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Guz.
SP.P: Don Pedro, I have a great regard both for you and yours, but I cannot suffer Don Carlos to stay longer in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Car.
SP.P: Conscious of the indelicacy, I will quit it immediately. Nay more, I will for some months, or longer if you please, return to my exile at Lisbon; yet let me hope, that time may open a way to our re-union, at least so far—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.P: I assure you, Don Guzman, when you hear the history of the three last days Don Carlos has past, you will allow there is something so uncom∣mon, and extraordinary—

SP.SPEAKER: Musk.
SP.P: Nobody can give a better account of that matter than I; and whenever Don Guzman permits me, I will do myself the honour to wait upon him, and entertain him with our whole adventure. In the mean time, to the very ground I thank him for all favours; wishing him health, happiness, and long life.—Of you also, young gentleman and lady, I take my leave:—and of you, Mrs. Beatrice, whom I will attend, within this week, to the mercer's, for a new silk gown; though I am oblig'd to pay for it out of my wages.—And, lastly, my dear master. I wish you joy, from the bottom of my heart, of being released from all your troubles, by the gene∣rosity of this good old gentleman: his beaviour has been that of a noble Spaniard; and I hope our friends will testify their satisfaction, by joining to applaud it.
